1009759_13_ITEM1_P0_S0	Capstone Turbine Corporation ("Capstone" or the "Company") develops, manufactures, markets and services microturbine technology solutions for use in stationary distributed power generation applications, including cogeneration (combined heat and power ("CHP"), integrated combined heat and power ("ICHP"), and combined cooling, heat and power ("CCHP")), renewable energy, natural resources and critical power supply.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P0_S1	In addition, our microturbines can be used as battery charging generators for hybrid electric vehicle applications.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P1_S0	Microturbines allow customers to produce power on-site in parallel with the electric grid or stand alone when no utility grid is available.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P2_S0	Several technologies are used to provide "on-site power generation" (also called "distributed generation") such as reciprocating engines, solar power, wind powered systems and fuel cells.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P2_S1	For customers who do not have access to the electric utility grid, microturbines provide clean, on-site power with lower scheduled maintenance intervals and greater fuel flexibility than competing technologies.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P2_S2	For customers with access to the electric grid, microturbines provide an additional source of continuous duty power, thereby providing additional reliability and potential cost savings.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P2_S3	With our stand-alone feature, customers can produce their own energy in the event of a power outage and can use microturbines as their primary source of power for extended periods.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P2_S4	Because our microturbines also produce clean, usable heat energy, they provide economic advantages to customers who can benefit from the use of hot water, chilled water, air conditioning and heating.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P2_S5	Our microturbines are sold primarily through our distributors.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P2_S6	Service is provided primarily by our global distribution network.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P2_S7	Together we offer new and remanufactured parts as well as a comprehensive Factory Protection Plan ("FPP").
1009759_13_ITEM1_P3_S0	Successful implementation of microturbines relies on the quality of the microturbine, marketability for appropriate applications, and the quality of the installation and support.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P4_S0	We believe we were the first company to offer a commercially available power source using microturbine technology.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P4_S1	Capstone offers microturbines designed for commercial, industrial, and utility users with product offerings ranging from 30 kilowatts ("kW") to one megawatt in electric power output.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P4_S2	Our 30 kW ("C30") microturbine can produce enough electricity to power a small convenience store.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P4_S3	The 65 kW ("C65") microturbine can produce enough heat to provide hot water to a 100-room hotel while also providing about one-third of its electrical requirements.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P4_S4	Our 200 kW ("C200") microturbine is well suited for larger hotels, office buildings and wastewater treatment plants, among others.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P4_S5	By packaging the C200 microturbine power modules into an International Organization for Standardization ("ISO") sized container, Capstone has created a family of microturbine offerings from 600 kW up to one megawatt in a compact footprint.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P4_S6	Our 1000 kW ("C1000 Series") microturbines are well suited for utility substations, larger commercial and industrial facilities and remote oil and gas applications.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P4_S7	Our microturbines combine patented air-bearing technology, advanced combustion technology and sophisticated power electronics to form efficient and ultra-low emission electricity and cooling and heat production systems.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P4_S8	Because of our air-bearing technology, our microturbines do not require liquid lubricants.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P4_S9	This means they do not require routine maintenance to change and dispose of oil or other liquid lubricants, as do the most common competing products.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P5_S0	Capstone microturbines can be fueled by various sources, including natural gas, propane, sour gas, renewable fuels such as landfill or digester gas, kerosene, diesel and biodiesel.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P5_S1	The C65 and C200 microturbines are available with integrated heat exchangers, making them easy to engineer and install in applications where hot water is used.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P6_S0	Our products produce exceptionally clean power.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P6_S1	Our C65 was certified by the California Air Resources Board ("CARB") as meeting its stringent 2007 emissions requirements the same emissions standard used to certify fuel cells and the same emissions levels as a state-of-the-art central power plant.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P6_S2	Our C65 Landfill and Digester Gas systems were certified in January 2008 by CARB as meeting 2008 waste gas emissions requirements for landfill and digester gas applications.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P7_S0	Digester Gas systems were certified in November 2010 by CARB as meeting 2008 waste gas emissions requirements for landfill and digester gas applications.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P8_S0	On February 1, 2010, we acquired the 100 kW ("TA100") microturbine product line from Calnetix Power Solutions, Inc. ("CPS") and entered into a manufacturing sub-contract agreement and an original equipment manufacturer agreement with selected exclusive rights to package a combined microturbine and waste heat recovery generator product.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P8_S1	The TA100 microturbine is most similar to the Capstone product design compared to other microturbine products in the industry and the 100 kW rating fits well between our C65 and C200 microturbines.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P8_S2	The 125 kW waste heat recovery generator can be directly fired by the exhaust of six C65 or two C200 microturbines to provide a total of over 500 kW of clean and efficient green power in applications where the microturbine exhaust is not otherwise utilized, such as CHP or CCHP.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P9_S0	We sell complete microturbine units, subassemblies, components and various accessories.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P9_S1	We also remanufacture microturbine engines and provide after-market parts and services.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P9_S2	Our microturbines are sold primarily through distributors and Original Equipment Manufacturers ("OEMs").
1009759_13_ITEM1_P9_S3	Distributors purchase our products for sale to end users and also provide application engineering and installation support.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P9_S4	Distributors are also required to provide a variety of additional services, including engineering the applications in which the microturbines will be used, installation support of the products at the end users' sites, commissioning the installed applications and providing post-commissioning service.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P9_S5	Our distributors perform as value-added resellers.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P10_S0	OEMs integrate Capstone's products into their own product solutions.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P11_S0	To assure proper installation of Capstone microturbine systems, we have instituted a Factory Trained Installer ("FTI") training and certification program.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P11_S1	Personnel from our distributors and OEMs, as well as design engineering firms, contractors and end users attend this FTI training.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P11_S2	We offer to assist all customers by reviewing their installation designs to confirm that the technical requirements for proper operation have been met, such as electrical interconnections, load requirements, fuel type and pressure, cooling air flow and turbine exhaust routing.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P11_S3	As part of the microturbine commissioning process, we also receive a checklist to confirm that the final installation adheres to Capstone technical requirements before we accept any warranty obligations.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P11_S4	This is aimed at providing the end user with a proper installation that will operate as expected for the life of the equipment.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P12_S0	Capstone has a factory direct service offering for commissioning and post-commissioning service.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P12_S1	Through our global distribution network, we offer a comprehensive FPP for a fixed annual fee to perform regularly scheduled and unscheduled maintenance as needed.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P12_S2	In January 2011, we expanded the FPP to include total microturbine plant operations if required by the end use customer.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P13_S0	Capstone provides factory and on-site training to certify all personnel that are allowed to perform service on our microturbines.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P13_S1	Individuals who are certified are called Authorized Service Providers ("ASPs") and must be employed by a distributor in order to perform work pursuant to a Capstone FPP.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P13_S2	The majority of our distributors provide these services.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P14_S0	This Annual Report on Form 10-K (this "Form 10-K") refers to Capstone's fiscal years ending March 31 as its "Fiscal" years.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P15_S0	We began commercial sales of our C30 products in 1998, targeting the emerging distributed generation industry that was being driven by fundamental changes in power requirements.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P15_S1	In September 2000, we shipped the first commercial unit of our 60 kW microturbine ("C60"), which was replaced by the C65 model during the quarter ended March 31, 2006.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P15_S2	We began shipping the C60 Integrated CHP solution in 2003.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P15_S3	The first commercial C200 microturbine was shipped on August 28, 2008.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P16_S0	Our C1000 Series product was developed based on Capstone's C200 microturbine engine.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P17_S0	The first commercial shipment of our C1000 Series product was on December 29, 2008.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P17_S1	We began shipping TA100 microturbines in March 2010.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P18_S0	During Fiscal 2013, we booked total orders of $112.6 million for 765 units, or 107.2 megawatts, compared to $122.5 million for 637 units, or 136.3 megawatts, during Fiscal 2012.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P18_S1	We shipped 628 units with an aggregate of 103.2 megawatts, generating revenue of $102.7 million compared to 627 units with an aggregate of 96.1 megawatts, generating revenue of $89.9 million during Fiscal 2012.

1009759_13_ITEM1_P18_S5	However, based on historical experience management expects that a significant portion of our backlog may not be shipped within the next twelve months.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P18_S6	The timing of shipments is subject to change based on several variables (including customer deposits, payments, availability of credit and customer delivery schedule changes), most of which are not in our control and can affect the timing of our revenue.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P19_S0	The following table summarizes our backlog:
1009759_13_ITEM1_P20_S0	Capstone microturbines are compact, lightweight and environmentally friendly generators of electricity and heat compared to competing technologies.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P20_S1	They operate on the same principle as a jet engine with the added capability of using a variety of commercially available fuels.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P20_S2	For example, our microturbines can operate on low British Thermal Unit ("BTU") gas, which is gas with lower energy content, and can also operate on gas with a high amount of sulfur, known in the industry as sour gas.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P20_S3	Examples of these fuel sources include methane from facilities such as wastewater treatment plants, landfills and anaerobic digesters.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P21_S0	Our microturbines incorporate four major design features:
1009759_13_ITEM1_P22_S0	advanced combustion technology; patented air-bearing technology; digital power electronics; and remote monitoring capability.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P23_S0	Our advanced combustion technology allows Capstone microturbines to achieve low emissions with a design geared towards manufacturability.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P23_S1	These low emission levels not only provide an environmentally friendly product, but also eliminate permitting requirements in several municipalities for continuously operated onsite power generation.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P24_S0	The air-bearing system allows the microturbine's single moving assembly to produce power without the need for typical petroleum-based lubrication.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P25_S0	Air-bearings use a high-pressure field of air rather than petroleum lubricants.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P25_S1	This improves reliability and reduces maintenance such as oil changes.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P26_S0	The electronic controls manage critical functions and monitor operations of the microturbine.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P26_S1	For instance, our electronics control the microturbine's speed, temperature and fuel flow and communicate with external networks and building management systems.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P26_S2	The power electronics coordinate with the grid when the units are operated in a grid-connect mode and with the onboard battery when equipped for stand-alone mode.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P26_S3	All control functions are performed digitally.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P26_S4	Performance is optimized, resulting in lower emissions, higher reliability and high efficiency over a variable power range.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P27_S0	The electrical output of our units can be paralleled in multiple unit configurations through our Advanced Power Server product and a digital communications cable to serve larger installations requiring electrical loads up to ten megawatts.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P28_S0	connected to the electric utility grid as a current source; on a stand-alone basis as a voltage source; multipacked to support larger loads as a "virtual single" unit; and in dual mode, where the microturbine operates connected to the electric utility grid or operates independently.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P29_S0	We also offer C65 and C200 ICHP systems.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P29_S1	These systems combine the standard C65 and C200 microturbine unit with a Heat Recovery Module that provides electricity and heats water.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P30_S0	Our family of products is offered in the following configurations:
1009759_13_ITEM1_P31_S0	We offer various accessories for our products including rotary gas compressors with digital controls, heat recovery modules for CHP applications, dual mode controllers that allow automatic transition between grid connect and stand-alone modes, batteries with digital controls for stand-alone or dual-mode operations, power servers for large multipacked installations, protocol converters for Internet access, packaging options and miscellaneous parts such as frames, exhaust ducting and installation hardware.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P31_S1	We also sell microturbine components and subassemblies.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P32_S0	Our electronic controls manage microturbines using Capstone's proprietary software and advanced algorithms.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P33_S0	convert the variable frequency, up to a maximum of 1,600 Hertz and variable voltage power produced by the generator into a usable output of either 50 or 60 Hertz AC for stationary applications or DC for hybrid electric vehicle applications; and provide digital communications to externally maintain and control the equipment.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P34_S0	In addition, our proprietary Capstone Remote Monitoring Software ("CRMS") allows end users to remotely operate and manage the microturbine.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P34_S1	Unlike the technology of other power sources that require manual monitoring and maintenance, the CRMS allows end users to remotely and efficiently monitor performance, power generation and time of operation using our CRMS interface software with standard personal computers.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P34_S2	This remote capability can provide end users with power generation flexibility and cost savings.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P34_S3	Capstone is currently developing an Internet based system to provide real-time continuous remote monitoring and diagnostics to customers who purchase the service.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P35_S0	The C30 microturbines were initially designed to operate connected to an electric utility grid and to use a high pressure natural gas fuel source.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P35_S1	We have expanded our microturbine's functionality to operate with different fuels.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P35_S2	The combustor system remains the same for all fuels except for the fuel injectors, which currently vary between liquid and gaseous fuels.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P36_S0	The Capstone microturbine's multi-fuel capability provides significant competitive advantages with respect to some of our selected vertical markets.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P37_S0	Our C65 grid-connect and stand-alone microturbine power systems are listed by Underwriters Laboratories ("UL") as meeting the UL 2200 stationary engine generator standards and the UL 1741 utility interconnection requirements.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P37_S1	Our products are manufactured by processes that are ISO 9001:2000 and ISO 14001:2004 certified.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P38_S0	In 2002, the California Energy Commission certified our C30 and C60 microturbines as the first products to comply with the requirements of its "Rule 21" grid interconnection standard.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P38_S1	This standard streamlines the process for connecting distributed generation systems to the grid in California.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P38_S2	The benefits of achieving this standard include avoiding both costly external equipment procurement requirements and extensive site-by-site and utility-by-utility analysis.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P38_S3	Our protective relay functionality has also been recognized by the State of New York, which has pre-cleared our microturbines for connection to New York's electric utility grid.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P39_S0	Our C60 microturbine was the first combustion power generation product to be certified by the CARB as meeting its stringent distributed generation emissions standards that went into effect in 2003.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P39_S1	Our C65 microturbine now meets the even more stringent CARB 2007 standard for natural gas.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P40_S0	The TA100 microturbine offers a digital communication interface which can be connected to an external controller (not sold by Capstone) to provide multiple unit and dual mode dispatching functionality.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P40_S1	An external synchronization board is provided to parallel the electrical output in multiple unit configurations for stand-alone operation.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P41_S0	We are the first microturbine manufacturer to achieve UL Class I, Division 2 certification for operation in hazardous-area oil and gas applications.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P41_S1	These specially packaged systems are applied in oil and gas production areas with potentially explosive environments.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P42_S0	In September 2009, we received UL certification for our C200 grid-connect and stand-alone microturbine as meeting the UL 2200 stationary engine generator standards and the UL 1741 utility interconnection requirements.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P43_S0	In June 2010, we received UL certification for our C1000 Series grid-connect and stand-alone microturbine as meeting the UL 2200 stationary engine generator standards and the UL 1741 utility interconnection requirements.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P44_S0	Worldwide, stationary power generation applications vary from huge central stationary generating facilities up to 1,000 MW to back-up generators as small as two kW. Historically, power generation in most developed countries such as the United States has been part of a regulated utility system.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P44_S1	A number of developments related primarily to the deregulation of the utility industry as well as significant technology advances have broadened the range of power supply choices available to all types of customers.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P45_S0	Capstone products serve multiple vertical markets worldwide.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P45_S1	Within the markets served, we focus on vertical markets that we have identified as having the greatest near-term potential.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P45_S2	In the markets we are focusing on, which are energy efficiency, renewable energy, natural resources, critical power supply and mobile products, we have identified specific targeted vertical market segments.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P46_S0	Energy efficiency maximizes the use of energy produced by the microturbines, reduces emissions compared with traditional power generation and enhances the economic advantage to customers.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P46_S1	Energy efficiency uses both the heat and electric energy produced in the power generation process.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P46_S2	Using the heat and electricity created from a single combustion process increases the efficiency of the system from approximately 30% to 75% or more.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P46_S3	The increased operating efficiency reduces overall greenhouse gas emissions compared with traditional independent sources such as power generation and local thermal generation and, through displacement of other separate systems, can reduce operating costs.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P46_S4	Our microturbines' emissions of commonly found air pollutants ("criteria pollutants") such as nitrogen oxides ("NOx"), carbon monoxide ("CO") and volatile organic compounds ("VOCs") are lower than those from the on-site boilers that our CHP system displaces, meaning that local emissions of these pollutants are actually reduced when a Capstone energy efficiency CHP system is installed.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P46_S5	This high CHP efficiency also means more efficient use of fuel and can reduce net utility costs for end users.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P47_S0	The most common uses of heat energy include space heating and air conditioning, heating and cooling water, as well as drying and other applications.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P47_S1	For example, we have used the heat generated by the microturbines to supply hot water solutions for hotels, office buildings and retail, commercial and industrial customers.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P47_S2	When our microturbine exhaust drives an absorption chiller, the chiller produces chilled water for air conditioning and other uses.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P48_S0	There are energy efficiency markets for CHP and CCHP applications worldwide.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P48_S1	A study conducted for the US Department of Energy ("DOE") calculated the total potential energy efficiency CHP market in the United States to be over 35.5 gigawatts through 2020.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P49_S0	Many governments have encouraged more efficient use of the power generation process to reduce pollution, lower dependence on fossil fuels and control the cost of locally produced goods.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P49_S1	To access these markets, we have entered into agreements with distributors which have engineered energy efficiency CHP packages that utilize the hot exhaust air of the microturbine for heating water and also use the hot exhaust to run an absorption chiller for air conditioning.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P49_S2	We also offer our own integrated energy efficiency CHP and CCHP product for the C65, C200 and C1000 Series products.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P50_S0	Our microturbines can use renewable methane gases from landfills, wastewater treatment facilities and other biogas applications such as food processing and agricultural waste, referred to as green waste, and cow, pig and chicken manure.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P50_S1	They can burn these renewable waste gases with minimal emissions, thereby, in some cases, avoiding the imposition of penalties incurred for pollution while simultaneously producing electricity from this "free" renewable fuel for use at the site or in the surrounding areas.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P51_S0	outperform conventional combustion engines in a number of situations, including when the gas contains a high amount of sulfur.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P52_S0	Capstone released for sale the C65 stand-alone digester product for sale in the renewable energy market segment in 2007.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P52_S1	This product is targeted at remote villages in third-world countries with wastewater treatment facilities that offer a valuable source of fuel which can be converted to electricity.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P53_S0	A joint applications and engineering team evaluated the performance of the existing C65 digester gas system to ensure that the combustion system would be stable from 0 to 100% power output.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P53_S1	Minor controls changes were implemented to increase stability at low power levels.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P53_S2	The ability to convert this low BTU fuel to electricity along with the high reliability and low maintenance features of this product make it well suited for this market.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P54_S0	In February 2010, we entered into an agreement with CPS to purchase 125 kW waste heat recovery generators in exchange for certain minimum purchase requirements through December 2015.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P54_S1	Pursuant to this agreement, we have exclusive rights to sell the zero-emission waste heat recovery generator for all microturbine applications and for applications 500 kW or lower where the source of heat is the exhaust of a reciprocating engine used in a landfill application.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P55_S0	On a worldwide basis, there are thousands of locations where the drilling, production, compression and transportation of natural resources and other extraction and production processes create fuel byproducts, which traditionally have been released or burned into the atmosphere.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P55_S1	Our microturbines are installed in the natural resource market to be used in oil and gas exploration, production, compression and transmission sites both onshore and offshore as a highly reliable critical source of power generation.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P55_S2	In addition, our microturbines can use flare gas as a fuel to provide prime power.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P55_S3	Typically these oil and gas or mining operations have no electric utility grid and rely solely on Capstone's microturbine for reliable low emission power supply.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P56_S0	Many major oil and gas companies are exploring large shale reserves, or plays, in the United States.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P56_S1	In mid-2010 Capstone sold its first microturbines into the U.S. shale gas market in the Eagle Ford and Marcellus shale plays.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P56_S2	The market for Capstone microturbines in this industry is vast.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P57_S0	The shale gas market is expected to grow substantially, especially since the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's ("EPA") Clean Air Act has strict requirements for emissions levels at natural gas sites.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P58_S0	The C200 product is offered for sale configured to meet Class 1 Zone 2 hazardous location requirements for the oil and gas market.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P58_S1	Hazardous location requirements are met through package ventilation changes for purging and pressurizing package air to avoid potential flammable mixtures as well as controls for emergency disconnect of fuel and electrical sources.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P58_S2	The package is upgraded to stainless steel construction to withstand the corrosive offshore environments where these units are installed.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P58_S3	Oil and gas customers prefer the low maintenance and high reliability attributes offered by our turbines to ensure continued production.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P58_S4	Capstone also offers C30 and C65 microturbine products in similar configurations.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P59_S0	Because of the potentially catastrophic consequences of even momentary system failure, certain power users such as high technology and information systems companies require particularly high levels of reliability in their power service.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P59_S1	Capstone's critical power supply offerings are the world's only microturbine powered Uninterruptible Power Source ("UPS") solutions that can offer clean, IT-grade power produced from microturbines, the utility or a combination of both.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P59_S2	We offer two microturbine-powered UPS solutions that support prime and dispatched power options.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P59_S3	The Capstone UPSource microturbine-powered UPS solution provides prime or emergency power solutions.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P60_S0	Both critical power supply products offer 99.999999% reliability when the product has at least one independent backup.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P60_S1	Dual mode units operating in a prime power configuration can support a 150% overload for 10 seconds during transient conditions.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P60_S2	Dual mode units operating in grid parallel mode can provide customers a back-up power system with an economic return.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P60_S3	These systems offer high onsite energy efficiency when combined with a heat exchanger (CHP) to create hot water or with a chiller (CCHP) for air conditioning at these facilities.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P60_S4	This configuration, when combined with the Capstone Dual Mode Controller, can transition from the grid parallel mode to prime power mode in less than 10 seconds.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P61_S0	Our technology is also used in hybrid electric vehicle ("HEV") applications.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P61_S1	Our customers have applied our products in hybrid electric vehicles such as transit buses and trucks.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P61_S2	In these applications the microturbine acts as an onboard battery charger to recharge the battery system as needed.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P61_S3	The benefits of microturbine hybrids include extended range, fuel economy gains, quieter operation, reduced emissions and higher reliability compared with traditional internal combustion engines.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P62_S0	Internal combustion diesel engine manufacturers have been challenged for the last several years to develop technology improvements, prior to aftertreatment that reduce emissions to levels specified by the EPA and CARB 2007 and 2010 standards.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P62_S1	Many manufacturers are incorporating aftertreatment that increases upfront equipment costs, vehicle weight and life cycle costs and may reduce overall engine efficiency.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P63_S0	Our technology is also used in marine applications.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P63_S1	Our customers have applied our products in the commercial vessel and luxury yacht markets.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P63_S2	The most immediate market for our marine products is for use as ship axillaries.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P63_S3	In this application, the microturbines provide power to the vessel's electrical loads and, in some cases, the vessel is able to utilize the exhaust energy to increase the overall efficiency of the application, reducing overall fuel consumption and emissions.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P63_S4	The other application is similar to our HEV application where the vessel is driven by an electric propulsion system and the microturbine serves as an on board range extender.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P64_S0	Our marine customers use both our liquid fueled and natural gas products.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P65_S0	Liquefied natural gas (LNG) is in its early stages as a marine fuel, and the number of vessels powered by LNG is forecasted to double every two years over the next decade.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P65_S1	Vessel owners can receive the same benefits as users of stationary Capstone products: low emissions with no aftertreatment, long maintenance intervals, high reliability, low noise and no vibration.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P66_S0	We primarily sell our microturbine product, parts and service through distributors.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P66_S1	Our typical terms of sale include shipment of the products with title, care, custody and control transferring at our dock, payment due anywhere from in advance of shipment to 90 days from shipment, and warranty periods of approximately 15 to 18 months from shipment.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P66_S2	We typically do not have customer acceptance provisions in our agreements.

1009759_13_ITEM1_P67_S1	Many of these distributors serve multiple markets in their select geographic regions.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P67_S2	The primary markets served in this region have been energy efficiency, renewable energy, natural resources and mobile products.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P67_S3	The energy efficiency and natural resources vertical markets are expected to grow as a result of an increased supply of low price natural gas.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P68_S0	In developing our sales opportunities we have identified the need to address various requirements present in our target localities.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P68_S1	These requirements include electric grid interconnection standards, gas utility connection requirements, building and fire safety codes and various inspections and approvals.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P68_S2	The costs and scheduling ramifications of these various approvals can be significant to the completion of an installation.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P68_S3	Our goal is to work with the applicable regulating entities to establish compliant standards for the installation of our microturbines so that the costs and installation timelines are minimized for our customers.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P68_S4	Management believes that we can create market advantages for our products through enhancing the ease of deploying our distributed generation solutions.

1009759_13_ITEM1_P70_S0	Our market focus in Asia and Australia is energy efficiency, renewable energy and natural resources.

1009759_13_ITEM1_P76_S0	The market for our products is highly competitive.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P76_S1	Our microturbines compete with existing technologies such as reciprocating engines and may also compete with emerging distributed generation technologies, including solar power, wind-powered systems, fuel cells and other microturbines.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P77_S0	Many potential customers rely on the utility grid for their electrical power.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P78_S0	As many of our distributed generation competitors are large, well-established companies, they derive advantages from production economies of scale, worldwide presence, brand recognition and greater resources, which they can devote to product development or promotion.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P79_S0	Generally, power purchased from the electric utility grid is less costly than power produced by distributed generation technologies.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P79_S1	Utilities may also charge fees to interconnect to their power grids.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P79_S2	However, we can provide economic benefits to end users in instances where the waste heat from our microturbine has value (CHP and CCHP), where fuel costs are low (renewable energy/renewable fuels), where the costs of connecting to the grid may be high or impractical (such as remote power applications), where reliability and power quality are of critical importance, or in situations where peak shaving could be economically advantageous because of highly variable electricity prices.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P80_S0	Because Capstone microturbines can provide a reliable source of power and can operate on multiple fuel sources, management believes they offer a level of flexibility not currently offered by other technologies such as reciprocating engines.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P81_S0	Our reciprocating engine competitors have products and markets that are well developed and technologies that have been proven for some time.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P82_S0	A reciprocating engine, also known as an internal combustion engine, is similar to those used in automotive applications.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P82_S1	Reciprocating engines are popular for primary and back-up power applications despite higher levels of emissions, noise and maintenance.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P82_S2	These technologies, which typically have a lower up-front cost than microturbines, are currently produced by Caterpillar Inc., Cummins Inc., Deutz Corporation, GE Gas Engines which now includes Waukesha, MAN SE, Tecogen, Inc. and W rtsil Corporation, among others.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P83_S0	Our microturbines may also compete with other distributed generation technologies, including solar power, wind power systems and fuel cells.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P83_S1	Solar and wind powered systems produce no emissions.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P83_S2	The main drawbacks to solar and wind powered systems are their dependence on weather conditions, the utility grid and high capital costs that can often make these systems uneconomical without government subsidies depending upon geographic locale and application of the technology.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P83_S3	Although the market for fuel cells is still developing, a number of companies are focused on markets similar to ours, including FuelCell Energy Inc., ClearEdge Power, Bloom Energy Corporation, LG Fuel Cell Systems, a business unit of LG Electronics, Plug Power Inc. and Ballard Power Systems Inc.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P84_S0	Fuel cells have lower levels of NOx, CO, VOCs and other criteria pollutant emissions than our microturbines.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P84_S1	Fuel cells, like solar and wind powered systems, have received higher levels of incentives for the same type of applications as microturbines.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P84_S2	Management believes that, absent these higher government incentives, microturbines provide a better value to end users in most applications.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P84_S3	However, over the medium-to-long term, fuel cell technologies that compete more directly with our products may be introduced.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P85_S0	We also compete with other companies who have microturbine products, including FlexEnergy and Turbec S.p.A.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P86_S0	Overall, we compete with end users' other options for electrical power and heat generation on the basis of our microturbine's ability to:
1009759_13_ITEM1_P87_S0	provide power when a utility grid is not available or goes out of service; reduce total cost of purchasing electricity and fuel; improve electric power availability and provide high power quality; operate on multiple fuel types; reduce emissions (both criteria pollutants and greenhouse gases); simplify operation; and control maintenance costs and associated disposal of hazardous materials.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P88_S0	Our markets can be positively or negatively impacted by the effects of governmental and regulatory matters.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P88_S1	We are affected not only by energy policy, laws, regulations and incentives of governments in the markets in which we sell, but also by rules, regulations and costs imposed by utilities.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P89_S0	Utility companies or governmental entities may place barriers on the installation or interconnection of our product with the electric grid.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P89_S1	Further, utility companies may charge additional fees to customers who install on-site power generation, thereby reducing the electricity they take from the utility, or for having the capacity to use power from the grid for back-up or standby purposes.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P89_S2	These types of restrictions, fees or charges could hamper the ability to install or effectively use our product or increase the cost to our potential customers for using our systems.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P89_S3	This could make our systems less desirable, thereby adversely affecting our revenue and profitability.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P89_S4	In addition, utility rate reductions can make our products less competitive which would have a material adverse effect on our operations.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P89_S5	These costs, incentives and rules are not always the same as those faced by technologies with which we compete.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P89_S6	However, rules, regulations, laws and incentives could also provide an advantage to our distributed generation solutions as compared with competing technologies if we are able to achieve required compliance in a lower cost, more efficient manner.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P89_S7	Additionally, reduced emissions and higher fuel efficiency could help our customers combat the effects of global warming.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P89_S8	Accordingly, we may benefit from increased government regulations that impose tighter emission and fuel efficiency standards.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P90_S0	Capstone continues to engage with Federal and State policymakers to develop government programs to promote the deployment of Capstone's low emission and energy efficient products.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P90_S1	In 2012, President Obama called for 40 GW of additional CHP power generation to be installed in the United States by 2020.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P91_S0	Legislation is under consideration by Congress that could stimulate the market for Capstone products by providing incentives to encourage energy efficiency.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P91_S1	We cannot provide assurance that any such legislation will be enacted, however, or that it will benefit us if enacted.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P92_S0	Several state programs were introduced in 2011 and 2012 that provide financial support to combined heat and power projects, and some of these programs have begun to benefit Capstone's customers.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P92_S1	For example, in New York, Capstone systems are pre-qualified for financial incentives available through the NYSERDA CHP Acceleration Program.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P92_S2	In Ohio, legislation passed allowing for CHP to qualify as an energy efficiency measure under the state's Energy Efficiency Resource Standard.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P93_S0	The United States Government is focused on promoting exports of American products with a specific emphasis on clean energy goods.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P93_S1	Capstone participates in export promotion activities such as trade missions which help us enter new markets by facilitating interactions with foreign buyers and distributors.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P93_S2	Capstone's customers have utilized trade financing through the Export-Import Bank of the United States ("Ex-Im Bank") in the past, and Capstone has seen more customers use Ex-Im Bank financing for projects in 2011 and 2012.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P94_S0	Government funding can impact the rate of development of new technologies.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P94_S1	While we continue to receive development funding, committed amounts remaining are relatively low.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P94_S2	Competing new technologies generally receive larger incentives and development funding than do microturbines.

1009759_13_ITEM1_P106_S0	In September 2011, we received CARB certification to the 2007 Fossil Fuel Standards for our C200 ICHP microturbine power systems.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P106_S1	This standard represents the most stringent emissions standard worldwide set to the Best Available Control Technology ("BACT") for large central power plants.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P106_S2	To put these emissions levels in perspective, it is challenging to measure the extremely low levels required with today's best emissions measurement equipment.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P106_S3	These emissions levels were achieved through scaling and optimization of Capstone existing lean premix combustion technology.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P106_S4	Test emissions from both the C30 and C65 natural gas fueled microturbines measured dramatically less than the emissions levels set forth by the CARB standard including NOx at 75% and CO at 96% less than the required levels.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P106_S5	The emissions levels are set so low that the California Air Resources Board has not defined any further limit reductions in the foreseeable future.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P107_S0	We continue to release variants of the C200 product to provide the same features that we offer customers with our C30 and C65 microturbine products.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P108_S0	A liquid fuel version of the C200 product has been developed with Capstone's lean premix combustion technology.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P108_S1	This technology allows operation on various fuels by changing the injector to achieve the necessary fuel to air ratio mixture, fuel atomization, stability, and exhaust emission levels.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P108_S2	The control system is modified to incorporate required algorithm modifications for start/stop sequencing and load state operation.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P109_S0	Liquid fuel products are well suited for markets where customers do not have access to gaseous fuels but still demand the low emissions, low maintenance, and high reliability benefits offered by Capstone's microturbine products.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P110_S0	Capstone received the 2011 NOVA Award from the Construction Innovation Forum ("CIF") for its C65 Hybrid Uninterruptible Power Supply ("UPS") Microturbine at Syracuse University's data center labeled one of the greenest data centers in the world.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P110_S1	The product utilizes Capstone's inverter electronics and controls technology to provide continuous power quality to the customer critical load.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P110_S2	The load inverter is connected through a central power bus to provide power from one of three available power sources including the utility grid, battery storage system, or microturbine generator.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P110_S3	Power to the critical load is synchronized to an available utility grid to allow direct bypass of the critical load to the utility grid.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P110_S4	This redundant functionality is provided in a single integrated package that can be scaled to a larger seamless power unit through Capstone's multipack feature.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P110_S5	These units can also be combined with a heat recovery module or an absorption chiller to provide higher total output efficiency.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P111_S0	operation year round allowing customers the ability to receive a payback on their capital equipment investment.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P111_S1	In November 2012, we received UL certification for our C65 HUPS microturbine system as meeting the UL 2200 stationary engine generator standards and the UL 1741 utility interconnection requirements.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P112_S0	We are continuing to work on product improvements to our C30 and C65 microturbine products targeted at the hybrid electric bus and truck market.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P113_S0	Because of Capstone's single moving assembly, manufacturers believe there is also the opportunity to produce a lower cost product in larger automotive volumes.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P113_S1	Our current focus is on a next generation product that would include existing components and a liquid-cooled set of electronics that are consistent with the size, cost and cooling strategies employed on vehicles today.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P114_S0	During the 2011 Hybrid Truck User's Forum in Baltimore Maryland, it was announced that both Kenworth Truck Company and Peterbilt Motors Company are working with Capstone to demonstrate Class 7 and Class 8 microturbine range extended series hybrid trucks.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P114_S1	Both vehicles are concept trucks intended to quantify the performance, efficiency, and economic benefits of a microturbine-based series hybrid solution.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P114_S2	Future development efforts will be based on the lessons learned from these programs.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P114_S3	In the meantime, Capstone has other hybrid vehicle customers that will benefit from continued development of this technology.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P115_S0	The C65 Liquid Fuel microturbine demonstrated emissions levels which meet the CARB 2010 standards for Heavy Duty Diesel Engines ("HDDE").
1009759_13_ITEM1_P115_S1	These requirements are met using test procedures which evaluate emissions performance through start/stop and load transient cycles.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P115_S2	Capstone is able to meet these extremely low emissions requirements using its lean premix combustion technology with no aftertreatment.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P116_S0	Competitive reciprocating engine technologies require aftertreatment components that increase system cost, require frequent maintenance, and impact engine efficiency.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P116_S1	The C30 Liquid Fuel microturbine met these requirements in March 2009.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P116_S2	In August 2011, we announced configurations of the C30 and C65 compressed natural gas ("CNG") fueled microturbines that meet extremely low emission standards, including the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and CARB 2010 emissions requirements for On-Road Heavy Duty Diesel Engines for Urban Bus.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P116_S3	Test emissions from both the C30 and C65 Natural Gas microturbines measured dramatically less than the emissions levels set forth by the CARB standard including NOx at 75% and CO at 96% less than the required levels.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P117_S0	We believe that future products will require the implementation of On Board Diagnostic (OBD) controls to gain certification through the CARB.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P118_S0	Capstone is working with the Department of Energy ("DOE") on two next generation technology roadmap programs, including the Flexible Fuel Turbine System ("FFTS") and High Efficiency Microturbine with integral heat recovery.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P118_S1	The FFTS program is aimed at developing a microturbine system for operation on a range of higher BTU gaseous fuels, including synthetic gas ("SynGas") produced by a biomass gasifier and hydrogen.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P119_S0	The High Efficiency Microturbine with integral heat recovery is focused on improving microturbine electrical efficiency and overall system efficiency utilizing heat recovery.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P119_S1	We are currently focusing efforts on the development of the High Efficiency Microturbine with integral heat recovery system.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P119_S2	In March 2013, Capstone successfully completed proof-of-concept testing of the first C250 that produced 270 kW as part of the first phase of development to increase power and electrical efficiency.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P119_S3	This milestone validates significant design and aero-performance work and marks the most powerful engine ever produced by Capstone in the lab.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P119_S4	Capstone is also working to boost the power capability of the power electronics and electrical system required to support this higher power generator.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P119_S5	The second phase of the program is expected to incorporate further engine efficiency improvements, resulting in a product with a projected electrical efficiency of 42% and targeted power output of 370 kW. Improvements in efficiency are key to all markets as improved fuel efficiency benefits users through lower operating costs.
1009759_13_ITEM1_P119_S6	We expect to commercialize these products into the C200/C1000 product family upon successful project completion and acceptable technical readiness level.

1009759_13_ITEM1A_P10_S0	We maintain two Credit and Security Agreements, or the Agreements, with Wells Fargo Bank, National Association, ("Wells Fargo"), that provide us with a credit facility up to $15.0 million in the aggregate.
1009759_13_ITEM1A_P10_S1	At March 31, 2013, we had $13.5 million outstanding under this line of credit.
1009759_13_ITEM1A_P10_S2	Under this credit facility, we are required to satisfy specified financial and restrictive covenants.
1009759_13_ITEM1A_P10_S3	Failure to comply with these covenants could cause an event of default which, if not cured or waived, could require us to repay substantial indebtedness immediately or allow Wells Fargo to terminate the credit facility.
1009759_13_ITEM1A_P10_S4	In addition, we have pledged our accounts receivable, inventories, equipment, patents and other assets as collateral under the Agreements which would be subject to seizure by Wells Fargo if we were in default and unable to repay the indebtedness.
1009759_13_ITEM1A_P11_S0	Several times since entering into the Agreements, we have not been in compliance with certain covenants under the Agreements.
1009759_13_ITEM1A_P11_S1	In connection with each event of noncompliance, Wells Fargo waived the event of default and, on several occasions, we amended the Agreements in response to the default.
1009759_13_ITEM1A_P11_S2	If we had not obtained the default waivers, or if we are ever again in noncompliance, we would not be able to draw additional funds under the credit facility.
1009759_13_ITEM1A_P11_S3	The Agreement also defines an event of default to include a material adverse effect on our business, as determined by Wells Fargo.
1009759_13_ITEM1A_P11_S4	An event of default for this or any other reason, if not waived, would have a material adverse effect on the Company.

1009759_13_ITEM7_P1_S0	Capstone is the market leader in microturbines based on the number of microturbines sold.
1009759_13_ITEM7_P2_S0	We increased revenues during Fiscal 2013 compared to Fiscal 2012 despite the challenging economic conditions worldwide.
1009759_13_ITEM7_P2_S1	Management believes that our ongoing efforts to grow and broaden our distribution network along with continued market acceptance of our 200 kW ("C200") microturbine and 1000 kW ("C1000 Series") microturbines products were the primary reasons for our revenue growth during the year compared to Fiscal 2012.
1009759_13_ITEM7_P2_S2	Fiscal 2013 was characterized by strong demand for C200 and C1000 Series microturbines led by the North American natural resources vertical market, while weakness continued in the European market as a result of uncertain global economic conditions.
1009759_13_ITEM7_P2_S3	Domestic demand was strong; sales from our U.S. based distributors during Fiscal 2013 were 45% of total revenue compared to 38% of total revenue during Fiscal 2012.
1009759_13_ITEM7_P2_S4	Management believes that sales in the natural resources vertical market will continue to grow and also expects the European market for our products will begin to recover during Fiscal 2014.
1009759_13_ITEM7_P2_S5	During Fiscal 2013 we received approximately 22 significant orders totaling approximately 54.4 megawatts, continued to make progress in manufacturing cost reduction and had record sales, continuing overall progress on our path to profitability.
1009759_13_ITEM7_P2_S6	In addition, we continue to make progress on our C250 product development initiative.
1009759_13_ITEM7_P2_S7	During Fiscal 2013, we experienced a higher rate of warranty claims than expected for C200 and C1000 Series systems.
1009759_13_ITEM7_P2_S8	Management expects warranty claims levels for C200 and C1000 Series systems to decline during Fiscal 2014 as reliability repair programs are completed and the products mature.
1009759_13_ITEM7_P3_S0	Capstone products continue to gain interest in all five of the major vertical markets (energy efficiency, renewable energy, natural resources, critical power supply and transportation products).
1009759_13_ITEM7_P3_S1	In the energy efficiency market, we continue to expand our market share in hotels, office buildings, hospitals, retail and industrial applications globally.
1009759_13_ITEM7_P3_S2	The renewable energy market continues to be a significant portion of our business as we shipped products around the globe for applications fueled by landfill gas, biodiesel, biogas such as food processing and agricultural waste, referred to as green waste, and cow, pig and chicken manure.
1009759_13_ITEM7_P3_S3	Our C1000 Series microturbine continues to drive our near term business success in the oil and gas and other natural resource markets as we gain product acceptance in U.S. shale plays and Russian oil fields.
1009759_13_ITEM7_P3_S4	Our critical power supply data center product is performing well, and we continue to focus efforts on gaining market share with this new product.
1009759_13_ITEM7_P3_S5	Capstone's transportation products market, utilizing microturbines for electric vehicles, is gaining interest for use of our products as range extenders in electric buses, trucks and the marine industry.
1009759_13_ITEM7_P4_S0	We continue to focus on improving our products based on customer input, building brand awareness and new channels to market by developing a diversified network of strategic distribution partners.
1009759_13_ITEM7_P4_S1	Our focus is on products and solutions that provide near-term opportunities to drive repeatable business rather than discrete projects for niche markets.
1009759_13_ITEM7_P4_S2	In addition, management closely manages operating expenses and strives to improve manufacturing efficiencies while simultaneously lowering direct material costs and increasing average selling prices.
1009759_13_ITEM7_P4_S3	The key drivers to Capstone's success are continued increase in C200 microturbine engine production rates, higher average selling prices, lower direct material costs, positive new order flow and reduced cash usage.

("CPS") pursuant to which we acquired, subject to an existing license retained by CPS, all of the rights and assets related to the manufacture and sale of the 100 kW ("TA100") microturbine generator, including intellectual property, design, tooling, drawings, patents, know-how, distribution agreements and supply agreements.
