1009759_14_ITEM15_P241_S0	The information contained in the Report fairly presents, in all material respects, the financial condition and results of operations of the Company.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P0_S0	Capstone Turbine Corporation ("Capstone" or the "Company") develops, manufactures, markets and services microturbine technology solutions for use in stationary distributed power generation applications, including cogeneration (combined heat and power ("CHP"), integrated combined heat and power ("ICHP"), and combined cooling, heat and power ("CCHP")), renewable energy, natural resources and critical power supply.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P0_S1	In addition, our microturbines can be used as battery charging generators for hybrid electric vehicle applications.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P1_S0	Microturbines allow customers to produce power on-site in parallel with the electric grid or stand alone when no utility grid is available.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P2_S0	Several technologies are used to provide "on-site power generation" (also called "distributed generation") such as reciprocating engines, solar power, wind powered systems and fuel cells.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P2_S1	For customers who do not have access to the electric utility grid, microturbines provide clean, on-site power with fewer scheduled maintenance intervals and greater fuel flexibility than competing technologies.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P2_S2	For customers with access to the electric grid, microturbines provide an additional source of continuous duty power, thereby providing additional reliability and potential cost savings.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P2_S3	With our stand-alone feature, customers can produce their own energy in the event of a power outage and can use microturbines as their primary source of power for extended periods.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P2_S4	Because our microturbines also produce clean, usable heat energy, they provide economic advantages to customers who can benefit from the use of hot water, chilled water, air conditioning and heating.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P2_S5	Our microturbines are sold, installed and serviced primarily through our global distribution network.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P2_S6	Together we offer new and remanufactured parts as well as a comprehensive Factory Protection Plan ("FPP").
1009759_15_ITEM1_P3_S0	Successful implementation of microturbines relies on the quality of the microturbine, marketability for appropriate applications, and the quality of the installation and support.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P4_S0	We believe we were the first company to offer a commercially available power source using microturbine technology.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P4_S1	Capstone offers microturbines designed for commercial, industrial and utility users with product offerings ranging from 30 kilowatts ("kW") to one megawatt in electric power output.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P4_S2	Our 30 kW ("C30") microturbine can produce enough electricity to power a small convenience store.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P4_S3	The 65 kW ("C65") microturbine can produce enough heat to provide hot water to a 100-room hotel while also providing about one-third of its electrical requirements.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P4_S4	Our 200 kW ("C200") microturbine is well suited for larger hotels, office buildings and wastewater treatment plants, among others.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P4_S5	By packaging the C200 microturbine power modules into an International Organization for Standardization ("ISO") sized container, Capstone has created a family of microturbine offerings from 600 kW up to one megawatt in a compact footprint.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P4_S6	Our 1000 kW ("C1000 Series") microturbines are well suited for utility substations, larger commercial and industrial facilities and remote oil and gas applications.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P4_S7	Our microturbines combine patented air-bearing technology, advanced combustion technology and sophisticated power electronics to form efficient and ultra-low emission electricity and cooling and heat production systems.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P4_S8	Because of our air-bearing technology, our microturbines do not require liquid lubricants.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P4_S9	This means they do not require routine maintenance to change and dispose of oil or other liquid lubricants, as do the most common competing products.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P5_S0	Capstone microturbines can be fueled by various sources, including natural gas, propane, sour gas, renewable fuels such as landfill or digester gas, kerosene, diesel and biodiesel.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P5_S1	The C65 and C200 microturbines are available with integrated heat exchangers, making them easy to engineer and install in applications where hot water is used.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P6_S0	Our products produce exceptionally clean power.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P6_S1	Our natural gas-fueled C65 and C200 microturbines were certified by the California Air Resources Board ("CARB") as meeting its stringent 2007 emissions requirements the same emissions standard used to certify fuel cells and the same emissions levels as a state-of-the-art central power plant.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P6_S2	Our C65 Landfill and Digester Gas systems were certified in January 2008 by CARB as meeting 2008 waste gas emissions requirements for landfill and digester gas applications.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P7_S0	November 2010 by CARB as meeting 2008 waste gas emissions requirements for landfill and digester gas applications.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P8_S0	On February 1, 2010, we acquired the 100 kW ("TA100") microturbine product line from Calnetix Power Solutions, Inc. ("CPS").
1009759_15_ITEM1_P8_S1	The TA100 microturbine is most similar to the Capstone product design compared to other microturbine products in the industry.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P9_S0	We sell complete microturbine units, subassemblies, components and various accessories.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P9_S1	We also remanufacture microturbine engines and provide after-market parts and services.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P9_S2	Our microturbines are sold primarily through distributors and Original Equipment Manufacturers ("OEMs").
1009759_15_ITEM1_P9_S3	Distributors purchase our products for sale to end users and also provide application engineering and installation support.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P9_S4	Distributors are also required to provide a variety of additional services, including engineering the applications in which the microturbines will be used, installation support of the products at the end users' sites, commissioning the installed applications and providing post-commissioning service.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P9_S5	Our distributors perform as value-added resellers.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P10_S0	OEMs integrate Capstone's products into their own product solutions.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P11_S0	To assure proper installation of Capstone microturbine systems, we have instituted a Factory Trained Installer ("FTI") training and certification program.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P11_S1	Personnel from our distributors and OEMs, as well as design engineering firms, contractors and end users attend this FTI training.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P11_S2	We offer to assist all customers by reviewing their installation designs to confirm that the technical requirements for proper operation have been met, such as electrical interconnections, load requirements, fuel type and pressure, cooling air flow and turbine exhaust routing.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P11_S3	As part of the microturbine commissioning process, we also receive a checklist to confirm that the final installation adheres to Capstone technical requirements before we accept any warranty obligations.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P11_S4	This is aimed at providing the end user with a proper installation that will operate as expected for the life of the equipment.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P12_S0	Through our global distribution network, we offer a comprehensive FPP for a fixed annual fee to perform regularly scheduled and unscheduled maintenance as needed.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P12_S1	Capstone provides factory and on-site training to certify all personnel that are allowed to perform service on our microturbines.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P12_S2	Individuals who are certified are called Authorized Service Providers ("ASPs"), and must be employed by a distributor in order to perform work pursuant to a Capstone FPP.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P12_S3	The majority of our distributors provide these services.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P13_S0	This Annual Report on Form 10-K (this "Form 10-K") refers to Capstone's fiscal years ending March 31 as its "Fiscal" years.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P14_S0	We began commercial sales of our C30 products in 1998, targeting the emerging distributed generation industry that was being driven by fundamental changes in power requirements.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P14_S1	In September 2000, we shipped the first commercial unit of our 60 kW microturbine ("C60"), which was replaced by the C65 model during the quarter ended March 31, 2006.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P14_S2	We began shipping the C60 ICHP solution in 2003.

1009759_15_ITEM1_P15_S1	The C1000 Series product can be configured into 1,000 kW, 800 kW and 600 kW solutions in a single ISO-sized container.

1009759_15_ITEM1_P16_S1	We shipped 620 units with an aggregate of 91.4 megawatts, generating revenue of $90.4 million compared to 671 units with an aggregate of 109.9 megawatts, generating revenue of $108.8 million during Fiscal 2014.

1009759_15_ITEM1_P17_S1	The decrease in backlog was primarily the result of the downturn of the oil markets, a substantially stronger U.S. dollar making our products more expensive overseas and on-going geopolitical tensions in Russia, North Africa and the Middle East.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P17_S2	The timing of the backlog is based on the requirement date indicated by our customers.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P17_S3	However, based on historical experience, management expects that a significant portion of our backlog may not be shipped within the next twelve months.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P17_S4	The timing of shipments is subject to change based on several variables (including customer deposits, payments, availability of credit and customer delivery schedule changes), most of which are not in our control and can affect the timing of our revenue.

1009759_15_ITEM1_P19_S0	Capstone microturbines are compact, lightweight and environmentally friendly generators of electricity and heat compared to competing technologies.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P19_S1	They operate on the same principle as a jet engine with the added capability of using a variety of commercially available fuels.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P19_S2	For example, our microturbines can operate on low British Thermal Unit ("BTU") gas, which is gas with lower energy content, and can also operate on gas with a high amount of sulfur, known in the industry as sour gas.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P19_S3	Examples of these fuel sources include methane from facilities such as wastewater treatment plants, landfills and anaerobic digesters.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P20_S0	Our microturbines incorporate four major design features:
1009759_15_ITEM1_P21_S0	advanced combustion technology; patented air-bearing technology; digital power electronics; and remote monitoring capability.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P22_S0	Our advanced combustion technology allows Capstone microturbines to achieve low emissions with a design geared towards manufacturability.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P22_S1	These low emission levels not only provide an environmentally friendly product, but also eliminate permitting requirements in several municipalities for continuously operated onsite power generation.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P23_S0	The air-bearing system allows the microturbine's single moving assembly to produce power without the need for typical petroleum-based lubrication.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P23_S1	Air-bearings use a high-pressure field of air rather than petroleum lubricants.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P23_S2	This improves reliability and reduces maintenance such as oil changes.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P24_S0	The electronic controls manage critical functions and monitor operations of the microturbine.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P24_S1	For instance, our electronics control the microturbine's speed, temperature and fuel flow and communicate with external networks and building management systems.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P24_S2	The power electronics coordinate with the grid when the units are operated in a grid-connect mode and with the onboard battery when equipped for stand-alone mode.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P25_S0	Performance is optimized, resulting in lower emissions, higher reliability and high efficiency over a variable power range.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P26_S0	The electrical output of our units can be paralleled in multiple unit configurations through our Advanced Power Server product and a digital communications cable to serve larger installations requiring electrical loads up to ten megawatts.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P27_S0	connected to the electric utility grid as a current source; on a stand-alone basis as a voltage source; multipacked to support larger loads as a "virtual single" unit; and in dual mode, where the microturbine operates connected to the electric utility grid or operates independently.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P28_S0	We also offer C65 and C200 ICHP systems.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P28_S1	These systems combine the standard C65 and C200 microturbine unit with a heat recovery module that provides electricity and heats water.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P29_S0	Our family of products is offered in the following configurations:
1009759_15_ITEM1_P30_S0	We offer various accessories for our products including rotary gas compressors with digital controls, heat recovery modules for CHP applications, dual mode controllers that allow automatic transition between grid connect and stand-alone modes, batteries with digital controls for stand-alone or dual-mode operations, power servers for large multipacked installations, protocol converters for Internet access, packaging options and miscellaneous parts such as frames, exhaust ducting and installation hardware.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P30_S1	We also sell microturbine components and subassemblies.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P31_S0	Our electronic controls manage microturbines using Capstone's proprietary software and advanced algorithms.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P32_S0	start the turbogenerator and manage its load; coordinate the functioning of the microturbine with the grid; manage the speed, fuel flow and exhaust temperature of the microturbine; convert the variable frequency, up to a maximum of 1,600 Hertz and variable voltage power produced by the generator into a usable output of either 50 or 60 Hertz AC for stationary applications or DC for hybrid electric vehicle applications; and provide digital communications to externally maintain and control the equipment.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P33_S0	In addition, our proprietary Capstone Remote Monitoring Software ("CRMS") allows end users to remotely operate and manage the microturbine.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P33_S1	Unlike the technology of other power sources that require on-site monitoring and maintenance, the CRMS allows end users to remotely and efficiently monitor their microturbine systems.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P33_S2	This remote capability can provide end users with power generation flexibility and cost savings.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P34_S0	The C30 microturbines were initially designed to operate connected to an electric utility grid and to use a high pressure natural gas fuel source.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P34_S1	We have expanded our microturbine's functionality to operate with different fuels.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P34_S2	The combustor system remains the same for all fuels except for the fuel injectors, which currently vary between liquid and gaseous fuels.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P35_S0	The Capstone microturbine's multi-fuel capability provides significant competitive advantages with respect to some of our selected vertical markets.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P36_S0	Our C65 grid-connect and stand-alone microturbine power systems are listed by Underwriters Laboratories ("UL") as meeting the UL 2200 stationary engine generator standards and the UL 1741 utility interconnection requirements.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P36_S1	Our products are manufactured by processes that are ISO 9001:2008 and ISO 14001:2004 certified.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P37_S0	In 2002, the California Energy Commission certified our C30 and C60 microturbines as the first products to comply with the requirements of its "Rule 21" grid interconnection standard.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P37_S1	This standard streamlines the process for connecting distributed generation systems to the grid in California.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P37_S2	The benefits of achieving this standard include avoiding both costly external equipment procurement requirements and extensive site-by-site and utility-by-utility analysis.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P37_S3	Our protective relay functionality has also been recognized by the State of New York, which has pre-cleared our microturbines for connection to New York's electric utility grid.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P38_S0	Our C60 microturbine was the first combustion power generation product to be certified by the CARB as meeting its stringent distributed generation emissions standards that went into effect in 2003.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P38_S1	Our C65 microturbine now meets the even more stringent CARB 2007 standard for natural gas.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P39_S0	The TA100 microturbine offers a digital communication interface which can be connected to an external controller (not sold by Capstone) to provide multiple unit and dual mode dispatching functionality.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P39_S1	An external synchronization board is provided to parallel the electrical output in multiple unit configurations for stand-alone operation.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P40_S0	We are the first microturbine manufacturer to achieve UL Class I, Division 2 certification for operation in hazardous-area oil and gas applications.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P40_S1	These specially packaged systems are applied in oil and gas production areas with potentially explosive environments.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P40_S2	In September 2009, we received UL certification for our C200 grid-connect and stand-alone microturbine as meeting the UL 2200 stationary engine generator standards and the UL 1741 utility interconnection requirements.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P40_S3	In June 2010, we received UL certification for our C1000 Series grid-connect and stand-alone microturbine as meeting the UL 2200 stationary engine generator standards and the UL 1741 utility interconnection requirements.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P41_S0	Worldwide, stationary power generation applications vary from huge central stationary generating facilities up to 1,000 MW to back-up generators as small as 2 kW. Historically, power generation in most developed countries such as the United States has been part of a regulated utility system.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P41_S1	A number of developments related primarily to the deregulation of the utility industry as well as significant technology advances have broadened the range of power supply choices available to all types of customers.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P42_S0	Capstone products serve multiple vertical markets worldwide.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P42_S1	Within the markets served, we focus on vertical markets that we have identified as having the greatest near-term potential.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P43_S0	we are focusing on, which are energy efficiency, renewable energy, natural resources, critical power supply, transportation and marine, we have identified specific targeted vertical market segments.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P44_S0	Energy efficiency maximizes the use of energy produced by the microturbines, reduces emissions compared with traditional power generation and enhances the economic advantage to customers.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P44_S1	Energy efficiency uses both the heat and electric energy produced in the power generation process.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P44_S2	Using the heat and electricity created from a single combustion process increases the efficiency of the system from approximately 30% to 75% or more.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P44_S3	The increased operating efficiency reduces overall greenhouse gas emissions compared with traditional independent sources such as power generation and local thermal generation and, through displacement of other separate systems, can reduce operating costs.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P44_S4	Our microturbines' emissions of commonly found air pollutants ("criteria pollutants"), such as nitrogen oxides ("NOx"), carbon monoxide ("CO") and volatile organic compounds ("VOCs"), are lower than those from the on-site boilers that our CHP system displaces, meaning that local emissions of these pollutants are actually reduced when a Capstone energy efficiency CHP system is installed.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P44_S5	This high CHP efficiency also means more efficient use of fuel and can reduce net utility costs for end users.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P45_S0	The most common uses of heat energy include space heating and air conditioning, heating and cooling water, as well as drying and other applications.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P45_S1	For example, we have used the heat generated by the microturbines to supply hot water solutions for hotels, office buildings and retail, commercial and industrial customers.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P45_S2	When our microturbine exhaust drives an absorption chiller, the chiller produces chilled water for air conditioning and other uses.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P46_S0	There are energy efficiency markets for CHP and CCHP applications worldwide.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P46_S1	A U.S. Department of Energy ("DOE") report cited the total technical potential for the energy efficiency CHP at commercial, institutional and industrial sites in the United States to be over 130 gigawatts.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P47_S0	Many governments have encouraged more efficient use of the power generation process to reduce pollution, lower dependence on fossil fuels and control the cost of locally produced goods.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P47_S1	To access these markets, we have entered into agreements with distributors which have engineered energy efficiency CHP packages that utilize the hot exhaust air of the microturbine for heating water and also use the hot exhaust to run an absorption chiller for air conditioning.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P47_S2	We also offer our own integrated energy efficiency CHP and CCHP product for the C65, C200 and C1000 Series products.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P48_S0	Our microturbines can use renewable methane gases from landfills, wastewater treatment facilities and other biogas applications such as food processing and agricultural waste, referred to as green waste, and cow, pig and chicken manure.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P48_S1	They can burn these renewable waste gases with minimal emissions, thereby, in some cases, avoiding the imposition of penalties incurred for pollution while simultaneously producing electricity from this "free" renewable fuel for use at the site or in the surrounding areas.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P48_S2	The microturbines have demonstrated effectiveness in these applications and outperform conventional combustion engines in a number of situations, including when the gas contains a high amount of sulfur.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P49_S0	Capstone released for sale the C65 stand-alone digester product in the renewable energy market segment in 2007.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P49_S1	This product is targeted at remote villages in third-world countries with wastewater treatment facilities that offer a valuable source of fuel which can be converted to electricity.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P50_S0	A joint applications and engineering team evaluated the performance of the existing C65 digester gas system to ensure that the combustion system would be stable from 0 to 100% power output.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P50_S1	Minor controls changes were implemented to increase stability at low power levels.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P50_S2	The ability to convert this low BTU fuel to electricity along with the high reliability and low maintenance features of this product make it well suited for this market.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P51_S0	On a worldwide basis, there are thousands of locations where the drilling, production, compression and transportation of natural resources and other extraction and production processes create fuel byproducts, which traditionally have been released or burned into the atmosphere.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P51_S1	Our microturbines are installed in the natural resource market to be used in oil and gas exploration, production, compression and transmission sites both onshore and offshore as a highly reliable critical source of power generation.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P51_S2	In addition, our microturbines can use flare gas as a fuel to provide prime power.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P51_S3	Typically these oil and gas or mining operations have no electric utility grid and rely solely on Capstone's microturbine for reliable low emission power supply.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P52_S0	Many major oil and gas companies are exploring large shale reserves, or plays, in the United States.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P52_S1	In mid-2010 Capstone sold its first microturbines into the U.S. shale gas market in the Eagle Ford and Marcellus shale plays.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P52_S2	The addressable market for Capstone microturbines in this industry is significant.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P52_S3	The shale gas market for microturbines is expected to grow substantially as demand for natural gas continues to rise and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency ("EPA"), the Department of the Interior and other federal and state agencies work to reduce emissions of methane, volatile organic compounds and hazardous air pollutants associated with natural gas development.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P52_S4	Capstone has been invited to participate in numerous Natural Gas STAR workshops in the United States and foreign markets to demonstrate the emissions reductions our technology can provide.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P53_S0	The C200 product is offered for sale configured to meet Class 1 Zone 2 hazardous location requirements for the oil and gas market.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P53_S1	Hazardous location requirements are met through package ventilation changes for purging and pressurizing package air to avoid potential flammable mixtures as well as controls for emergency disconnect of fuel and electrical sources.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P53_S2	The package is upgraded to stainless steel construction to withstand the corrosive offshore environments where these units are installed.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P53_S3	Oil and gas customers prefer the low maintenance and high reliability attributes offered by our turbines to ensure continued production.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P53_S4	Capstone also offers C30 and C65 microturbine products in similar configurations.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P54_S0	Because of the potentially catastrophic consequences of even momentary system failure, certain power users such as high technology, health care and information systems facilities require particularly high levels of reliability in their power service.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P54_S1	To meet these customer requirements, traditional solutions utilize Uninterruptible Power Supplies ("UPS") to protect critical loads from momentary power disturbances along with backup diesel generators for extended outages.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P54_S2	Capstone offers an alternative solution that can both meet customer reliability requirements and reduce operating costs.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P55_S0	Capstone has developed the world's only microturbine powered UPS solutions that offer clean, IT-grade power and can completely displace the need for traditional UPS and backup diesel generators.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P56_S0	We offer two microturbine-powered UPS solutions.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P57_S0	The Capstone UPSource microturbine-powered UPS solution provides prime or emergency power solutions.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P57_S1	Capstone's Hybrid UPS microturbine powered solution provides power when dispatched in high efficiency, standard UPS and emergency power solutions.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P57_S2	Both critical power supply products offer 99.999999% availability in an n+1 configuration when the product has at least one independent backup.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P57_S3	Our microturbine-powered UPS solutions are UL listed.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P57_S4	These integrated solutions are ideal for new construction or facility expansion and are typically installed with absorption chillers or other heat recovery systems to obtain high efficiency and reduce operating costs compared with traditional solutions.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P58_S0	Dual mode units operating in a prime power configuration can support a 150% overload for 10 seconds during transient conditions.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P58_S1	Dual mode units operating in grid parallel mode can provide customers a back-up power system with an economic return.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P59_S0	for air conditioning at these facilities.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P59_S1	This configuration, when combined with the Capstone Dual Mode Controller, can transition from the grid parallel mode to prime power mode in less than ten seconds.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P59_S2	Capstone microturbines can also be installed along with a rotary UPS to provide a complete line-interactive continuous power solution.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P59_S3	In this case, the microturbines remain in grid connect mode while the rotary UPS stabilizes the utility voltage and provides a seamless transfer from operation connected to the grid to operation isolated from the grid.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P60_S0	Our technology is also used in hybrid electric vehicle ("HEV") applications.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P60_S1	Our customers have applied our products in hybrid electric vehicles such as transit buses and trucks.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P60_S2	In these applications the microturbine acts as an onboard battery charger to recharge the battery system as needed.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P60_S3	The benefits of microturbine hybrids include extended range, fuel economy gains, quieter operation, reduced emissions and higher reliability compared with traditional internal combustion engines.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P61_S0	Internal combustion diesel engine manufacturers have been challenged for the last several years to develop technology improvements, prior to aftertreatment that reduce emissions to levels specified by the EPA and CARB 2007 and 2010 standards.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P61_S1	Many manufacturers are incorporating aftertreatment that increases upfront equipment costs, vehicle weight and life cycle costs and may reduce overall engine efficiency.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P62_S0	Our technology is also used in marine applications.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P62_S1	Our customers have applied our products in the commercial vessel and luxury yacht markets.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P63_S0	The most immediate market for our marine products is for use as a ship auxiliary engine.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P63_S1	In this application, the microturbines provide power to the vessel's electrical loads and, in some cases, the vessel is able to utilize the exhaust energy to increase the overall efficiency of the application, reducing overall fuel consumption and emissions.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P63_S2	The other application is similar to our HEV application where the vessel is driven by an electric propulsion system and the microturbine serves as an on board range extender.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P64_S0	Our marine customers use both our liquid fueled and natural gas products.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P65_S0	Liquefied natural gas ("LNG") is in its early stages as a marine fuel, and the number of vessels powered by LNG is forecasted to double every two years over the next decade.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P65_S1	Vessel owners can receive the same benefits as users of stationary Capstone products: low emissions with no aftertreatment, long maintenance intervals, high reliability, low noise and no vibration.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P66_S0	We primarily sell our microturbine product, parts and service through distributors.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P66_S1	Our world-wide distribution network is our most valuable intangible asset that we have proudly developed from the ground up.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P66_S2	Each one of our distributors is a strategically placed independent partner of Capstone marketing and selling the Capstone products and services on our behalf.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P66_S3	Our typical terms of sale include shipment of the products with title, care, custody and control transferring at our dock, payment due anywhere from in advance of shipment to 90 days from shipment, and warranty periods of approximately 15 to 18 months from shipment.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P66_S4	We typically do not have customer acceptance provisions in our agreements.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P67_S0	We have distribution agreements with a number of companies throughout North America for the resale of our products.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P67_S1	Many of these distributors serve multiple markets in their select geographic regions.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P67_S2	The primary markets served in this region have been energy efficiency, renewable energy, natural resources, critical power and mobile products.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P67_S3	The energy efficiency and natural resources vertical markets are expected to grow as a result of an increased domestic production of hydrocarbons, the low downstream price of natural gas and public and regulatory acceptance of distributed generation.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P68_S0	Recent energy reform in Mexico has opened new market opportunities by allowing competition and enabling power generation companies to sell directly to consumers instead of only to the state-owned Federal Electricity Commission.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P68_S1	Capstone's strategy in Mexico is to leverage our distribution network in Mexico across various market verticals.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P69_S0	In developing our sales opportunities we have identified the need to address various requirements present in our target localities.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P69_S1	These requirements include electric grid interconnection standards, gas utility connection requirements, emissions standards, building and fire safety codes and various inspections and approvals.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P69_S2	The costs and scheduling ramifications of these various approvals, in conjunction with normal bidding process requirements and construction delays, can be significant to the completion of an installation.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P69_S3	Our goal is to work with the applicable regulating entities to establish compliant standards for the installation of our microturbines so that the costs and installation timelines are minimized for our customers.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P69_S4	Management believes that we can create market advantages for our products through enhancing the ease of deploying our distributed generation solutions.

1009759_15_ITEM1_P71_S0	Our target markets in Asia and Australia are energy efficiency, renewable energy and natural resources.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P71_S1	Our historical sales in Southeast Asia and Australia have primarily been in the CHP, CCHP and the oil and gas market.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P71_S2	Other areas in Asia and the Pacific Rim offer attractive opportunities as well.

1009759_15_ITEM1_P82_S0	The market for our products is highly competitive.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P82_S1	Our microturbines compete with existing technologies such as reciprocating engines and may also compete with emerging distributed generation technologies, including solar power, wind-powered systems, fuel cells and other microturbines.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P83_S0	Many potential customers rely on the utility grid for their electrical power.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P84_S0	Many of our distributed generation competitors are large, well-established companies that derive competitive advantages from production economies of scale, worldwide presence, brand recognition and greater resources which they can devote to product development or promotion.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P85_S0	Generally, power purchased from the electric utility grid is less costly than power produced by distributed generation technologies.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P85_S1	Utilities may also charge fees to interconnect to their power grids.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P85_S2	However, we can provide economic benefits to end users in instances where the waste heat from our microturbine has value (CHP and CCHP), where fuel costs are low (renewable energy/renewable fuels), where the costs of connecting to the grid may be high or impractical (such as remote power applications), where reliability and power quality are of critical importance, or in situations where peak shaving could be economically advantageous because of highly variable electricity prices.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P86_S0	Because Capstone microturbines can provide a reliable source of power and can operate on multiple fuel sources, management believes they offer a level of flexibility not currently offered by other technologies such as reciprocating engines.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P87_S0	Our reciprocating engine competitors have products and markets that are well developed and technologies that have been proven for some time.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P88_S0	A reciprocating engine, also known as an internal combustion engine, is similar to those used in automotive applications.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P88_S1	Reciprocating engines are popular for primary and back-up power applications despite higher levels of emissions, noise and maintenance.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P88_S2	These technologies, which typically have a lower up-front cost than microturbines, are currently produced by Caterpillar Inc., Cummins Inc., Deutz Corporation, GE Gas Engines (which now includes Waukesha and Jenbacher), MAN SE, Tecogen, Inc. and W rtsil Corporation, among others.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P89_S0	Our microturbines may also compete with other distributed generation technologies, including solar power, wind power systems and fuel cells.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P89_S1	Solar and wind powered systems produce no emissions.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P89_S2	The main drawbacks to solar and wind powered systems are their dependence on weather conditions, the utility grid and high capital costs that can often make these systems uneconomical without government subsidies depending upon geographic locale and application of the technology.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P90_S0	Although the market for fuel cells is still developing, a number of companies are focused on markets similar to ours, including FuelCell Energy Inc., Bloom Energy Corporation, LG Fuel Cell Systems, a business unit of LG Electronics, Plug Power Inc. and Ballard Power Systems Inc.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P91_S0	Fuel cells have lower levels of NOx, CO, VOCs and other criteria pollutant emissions than our microturbines.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P91_S1	Fuel cells, like solar and wind powered systems, have received higher levels of incentives for the same type of applications as microturbines.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P91_S2	Management believes that, absent these higher government incentives, microturbines provide a better value to end users in most applications.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P91_S3	However, over the medium-to-long term, fuel cell technology companies may introduce products that compete more directly with our microturbines.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P92_S0	We also compete with other companies who have microturbine products, including FlexEnergy and Turbec S.p.A.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P93_S0	Overall, we compete with end users' other options for electrical power and heat generation on the basis of our microturbine's ability to:
1009759_15_ITEM1_P94_S0	provide power when a utility grid is not available or goes out of service; reduce total cost of purchasing electricity and fuel; improve electric power availability and provide high power quality; operate on multiple fuel types; reduce emissions (both criteria pollutants and greenhouse gases); simplify operation; and control maintenance costs and associated disposal of hazardous materials.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P95_S0	Our markets can be positively or negatively impacted by the effects of governmental and regulatory matters.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P95_S1	We are affected not only by energy policy, laws, regulations and incentives of governments in the markets in which we sell, but also by rules, regulations and costs imposed by utilities.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P96_S0	Utility companies or governmental entities may place barriers on the installation or interconnection of our product with the electric grid.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P96_S1	Further, utility companies may charge additional fees to customers who install on-site power generation; thereby reducing the electricity they take from the utility, or for having the capacity to use power from the grid for back-up or standby purposes.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P96_S2	These types of restrictions, fees or charges could hamper the ability to install or effectively use our product, or increase the cost to our potential customers for using our systems.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P96_S3	This could make our systems less desirable, thereby adversely affecting our revenue and profitability.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P96_S4	In addition, utility rate reductions can make our products less competitive which would have a material adverse effect on our operations.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P96_S5	These costs, incentives and rules are not always the same as those faced by technologies with which we compete.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P97_S0	However, rules, regulations, laws and incentives could also provide an advantage to our distributed generation solutions as compared with competing technologies if we are able to achieve required compliance in a lower cost, more efficient manner.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P97_S1	Additionally, reduced emissions and higher fuel efficiency could help our customers combat the effects of global warming.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P97_S2	Accordingly, we may benefit from increased government regulations that impose tighter emission and fuel efficiency standards.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P98_S0	Capstone continues to engage with federal and state policymakers to develop government programs to promote the deployment of Capstone's low emission and energy efficient products.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P99_S0	Kevin Mullin, Speaker Pro Tempore and Assembly member for California's 22 nd Assembly district, recently introduced A.B. 674 in the California legislature.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P99_S1	This bill may stimulate the market in California for Capstone products by revising utility charges and standby rates that apply to distributed generation projects.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P99_S2	We cannot provide assurance that any such legislation will be enacted, however.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P99_S3	In the wake of numerous destructive storms, several state and local governments are putting greater value in resilient distributed generation resources, including CHP and microgrids, and even reassessing the traditional utility model.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P99_S4	However, utilities in other states have asked public utility commissioners to revisit incentive programs and exemptions from grid usage charges for distributed generation technologies, arguing that these policies shift costs to other rate payers.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P100_S0	The United States Government is focused on promoting exports of American products with a specific emphasis on clean energy goods.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P100_S1	Capstone participates in export promotion activities such as trade missions which help us enter new markets by facilitating interactions with foreign buyers and distributors.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P101_S0	Government funding can impact the rate of development of new technologies.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P101_S1	While we continue to receive development funding, committed amounts remaining are relatively low.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P101_S2	Competing new technologies generally receive larger incentives and development funding than do microturbines.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P101_S3	There are certain recent federal funding solicitations that may support microturbine development.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P101_S4	We cannot provide any assurance that any proposal Capstone submits will be funded.

1009759_15_ITEM1_P119_S0	Capstone liquid fuel microturbines have demonstrated emissions levels which meet the CARB 2010 standards for Heavy Duty Diesel Engines ("HDDE").
1009759_15_ITEM1_P119_S1	Capstone is able to meet these extremely low emissions requirements using its lean premix combustion technology with no exhaust aftertreatment.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P120_S0	Competitive reciprocating engine technologies require aftertreatment components that increase system cost, require frequent maintenance, and impact engine efficiency.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P120_S1	Capstone's compressed natural gas ("CNG") fueled microturbines also meet extremely low emission standards, including the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and CARB 2010 emissions requirements for On-Road HDDE for Urban Bus.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P120_S2	Test emissions from our Natural Gas microturbines measured dramatically less than the emissions levels set forth by the CARB standard including NOx at 75% and CO at 96% less than the required levels.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P120_S3	These microturbines are now certified by CARB and available for production in Fiscal 2016.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P121_S0	Capstone is expanding into the marine sector through collaboration with vessel owners, shipyards, and its marine OEM partner, Microturbine Marine Energy.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P121_S1	Capstone's marine products can be used to provide hybrid electric marine propulsion, "hotel power," CHP, or CCHP.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P121_S2	They are especially ideal for small- and mid-size commercial ships that travel inland waterways and emissions controlled areas (ECAs).
1009759_15_ITEM1_P121_S3	A notable case study is the Deen Shipping's Argonon, where LNG fuels two C30 microturbines.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P121_S4	Both units have been in operation since 2011 and have saved 25 tons of diesel equivalents per year, compared to conventional accommodation heating and chilling.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P122_S0	for its marine products, which is expected in 2015.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P123_S0	Type Approval provides independent product verification that the product conforms to recognized industry quality standards, International Conventions and/or Marine Classification Society Rules, through a process of independent design review, sample testing and verification of production controls.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P124_S0	Capstone continues to evolve our C65 Hybrid UPS product line.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P124_S1	After having received the 2011 NOVA Award from the Construction Innovation Forum for the C65 Hybrid UPS Microturbine at Syracuse University's data center labeled one of the greenest data centers in the world, Capstone's C65 Hybrid UPS system has continued development and has recent installations at Sempra in Monterey Park, CA and Capstone's own Data Center in Chatsworth, CA.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P124_S2	The product utilizes Capstone's inverter electronics and controls technology to provide continuous power quality to meet the customer's critical load.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P124_S3	The load inverter is connected through a central power bus to provide power from one of three available power sources including the utility grid, battery storage system, or microturbine generator.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P124_S4	Power to the critical load is synchronized to an available utility grid to allow direct bypass of the critical load to the utility grid.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P124_S5	This redundant functionality is provided in a single integrated package that can be scaled to a larger seamless power unit through Capstone's multipack feature.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P124_S6	These units can also be combined with a heat recovery module or an absorption chiller to provide higher total output efficiency.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P124_S7	Unlike current UPS products combined with reciprocating engines for backup, the low emissions Capstone Hybrid UPS product allows for continuous operation year round allowing customers the ability to receive a payback on their capital equipment investment.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P125_S0	Capstone is working with the Department of Energy ("DOE") on two next generation technology roadmap programs, including a High Efficiency Microturbine with integral heat recovery and advanced AFA (Alumina Forming Austenitic) stainless steel material program in partnership with Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL).
1009759_15_ITEM1_P125_S1	The High Efficiency Microturbine with integral heat recovery is focused on improving microturbine electrical efficiency and overall system efficiency utilizing heat recovery.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P125_S2	We are currently focusing efforts on the development of the C370 Dual Spool High Efficiency Microturbine with integral heat recovery system.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P125_S3	In March 2013, Capstone successfully completed proof-of-concept testing of the low pressure spool also known as the C250 that produced 270 kW as part of the first phase of development.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P125_S4	This allowed Capstone to successfully achieve Phase Gate 2 requirements of the DOE contract and proceed with high pressure spool development.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P125_S5	Capstone also demonstrated and increased capability of the power electronics and electrical system required to support this higher power generator.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P125_S6	The final phase of the program, which is expected to be completed during Fiscal 2016, will incorporate further engine efficiency improvements, resulting in a product design with a projected electrical efficiency of 42% and targeted power output of 370 kW. Improvements in efficiency are key to all markets as improved fuel efficiency benefits users through lower operating costs.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P126_S0	AFA stainless steel is a material that offers superior oxidation and creep resistance to commercial heat-resistant steel alloys used in Capstone microturbines at a significantly reduced cost.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P127_S0	In Fiscal 2015, we successfully completed the first of two long term endurance tests and have engaged industry partners on commercialization viability.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P127_S1	In Fiscal 2017, we expect to complete the second endurance test, after which we will be positioned to make a commercialization decision.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P128_S0	We rely on a combination of patent, trade secret, copyright and trademark law and nondisclosure agreements to establish and protect our intellectual property rights in our products.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P128_S1	In this regard, we have obtained 103 U.S. and 34 international patents (in certain cases covering the same technology in multiple jurisdictions).
1009759_15_ITEM1_P128_S2	The patents we have obtained will expire between 2015 and 2027.
1009759_15_ITEM1_P129_S0	Management believes that a policy of protecting intellectual property is an important component of our strategy of being the leader in microturbine system technology and will provide us with a long-term competitive advantage.

1009759_15_ITEM1A_P10_S0	We maintain two Credit and Security Agreements (the "Agreements"), with Wells Fargo Bank, National Association, ("Wells Fargo"), that provide us with a credit facility up to $15.0 million in the aggregate.
1009759_15_ITEM1A_P10_S1	At March 31, 2015, we had $13.0 million outstanding under this line of credit.
1009759_15_ITEM1A_P10_S2	Under this credit facility, we are required to satisfy specified financial and restrictive covenants.
1009759_15_ITEM1A_P10_S3	Failure to comply with these covenants could cause an event of default which, if not cured or waived, could require us to repay substantial indebtedness immediately or allow Wells Fargo to terminate the credit facility.
1009759_15_ITEM1A_P10_S4	In addition, we have pledged our accounts receivable, inventories, equipment, patents and other assets as collateral under the Agreements which would be subject to seizure by Wells Fargo if we were in default and unable to repay the indebtedness.
1009759_15_ITEM1A_P11_S0	Several times since entering into the Agreements, we have not been in compliance with certain covenants under the Agreements.
1009759_15_ITEM1A_P11_S1	In connection with each event of noncompliance, Wells Fargo waived the event of default and, on several occasions, we amended the Agreements in response to the default.
1009759_15_ITEM1A_P11_S2	As of March 31, 2015, we were not in compliance with the annual net income financial covenant contained in the Agreements, as amended.
1009759_15_ITEM1A_P11_S3	On June 10, 2015, we received from Wells Fargo a waiver of such noncompliance.
1009759_15_ITEM1A_P11_S4	If we had not obtained the default waivers, or if we are ever again in noncompliance, we would not be able to draw additional funds under the credit facility.
1009759_15_ITEM1A_P11_S5	The Agreement also defines an event of default to include a material adverse effect on our business, as determined by Wells Fargo.
1009759_15_ITEM1A_P11_S6	An event of default for this or any other reason, if not waived, would have a material adverse effect on the Company.

1009759_15_ITEM1A_P112_S0	Our board of directors has adopted a stockholder rights plan, pursuant to which one preferred stock purchase right has been issued for each share of our common stock authorized and outstanding.
1009759_15_ITEM1A_P112_S1	Until the occurrence of certain prescribed events, the rights are not exercisable and are transferable along with, and only with, each share of our common stock and are evidenced by the common stock certificates.
1009759_15_ITEM1A_P112_S2	One preferred stock purchase right will also be issued with each share of our common stock we issue in the future until the rights plan expires or is terminated or we redeem or exchange the rights for other property in accordance with the terms of the rights plan or at such time, if any, as the rights separate from each share of our common stock and become exercisable.
1009759_15_ITEM1A_P113_S0	Each share of Series A Junior Participating Preferred Stock will be entitled to receive, when, as and if declared by our board of directors out of funds legally available for the purpose, dividends payable in cash in an amount per share (rounded to the nearest cent) equal to 100 times the aggregate per share amount of all dividends or other distributions, including non-cash dividends (payable in kind), declared on our common stock other than a dividend payable in shares of common stock or a subdivision of the outstanding shares of common stock.
1009759_15_ITEM1A_P114_S0	The rights plan prohibits the issuance of additional rights after the rights separate from our common stock.

1009759_15_ITEM7_P1_S0	Capstone is the market leader in microturbines based on the number of microturbines sold.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P2_S0	Generally, power purchased from the electric utility grid is less costly than power produced by distributed generation technologies.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P2_S1	Utilities may also charge fees to interconnect to their power grids.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P2_S2	However, we can provide economic benefits to end users in instances where the waste heat from our microturbine has value (combined heat and power ("CHP") and combined cooling, heat and power ("CCHP")), where fuel costs are low (renewable energy/renewable fuels), where the costs of connecting to the grid may be high or impractical (such as remote power applications), where reliability and power quality are of critical importance, or in situations where peak shaving could be economically advantageous because of highly variable electricity prices.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P3_S0	Because Capstone microturbines can provide a reliable source of power and can operate on multiple fuel sources, management believes they offer a level of flexibility not currently offered by other technologies such as reciprocating engines.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P4_S0	During Fiscal 2015 our net loss increased by 93% to $31.5 million and our net loss per share increased by 100% to $0.10 compared to the same period last year.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P4_S1	The increase in the net loss was primarily the result of lower revenue and accounts receivable allowance for two customers during Fiscal 2015 compared to the same period last year.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P4_S2	Please see Results of Operations on page 34 for further discussion on the lower revenue and accounts receivable allowance.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P4_S3	We continue to remain focused on improving our gross margin.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P4_S4	Our gross margin was 16% for each of Fiscal 2015 and Fiscal 2014.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P4_S5	While our year over year revenue decreased 13%, our gross margin rate remained flat compared to Fiscal 2014.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P4_S6	During Fiscal 2015 we benefitted from our ongoing efforts in manufacturing cost reductions that were entirely offset by lower volume and lower average selling prices for our microturbines compared to the same period last year.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P4_S7	Fiscal 2015 was characterized by lower revenue as our operational progress was eclipsed by challenging macroeconomic headwinds over the last year which included the dramatic downturn of the oil markets, a substantially stronger U.S. dollar making our products more expensive overseas and ongoing geopolitical tensions in Russia, North Africa and the Middle East; all of these factors negatively impacted our business.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P5_S0	Capstone products continue to gain interest in all six of the major vertical markets (energy efficiency, renewable energy, natural resources, critical power supply, marine and transportation).
1009759_15_ITEM7_P5_S1	In the energy efficiency market, we continue to expand our market presence in hotels, office buildings, hospitals, retail and industrial applications globally.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P6_S0	The renewable energy market is fueled by landfill gas, biodiesel, and biogas from sources such as food processing, agricultural waste and cow, pig and chicken manure.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P6_S1	Our success in the oil and gas and other natural resources market, which continues to be a growing market worldwide is driven by our microturbines reliability, emissions profile and ease of installation.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P6_S2	We have also seen increased interest in critical power supply solution applications as customers want solutions that can handle both primary and backup power.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P7_S0	Capstone's transportation market, which utilizes microturbines for electric vehicle industries, is gaining interest as liquid natural gas becomes more readily available as a transportation fuel and emission regulations continue to be tightened on the diesel engine industry.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P8_S0	Our focus is on products and solutions that provide near-term opportunities to drive repeatable business rather than discrete projects for niche markets.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P8_S1	In addition, management closely manages operating expenses and strives to improve manufacturing efficiencies while simultaneously lowering direct material costs and increasing average selling prices.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P8_S2	The key drivers to Capstone's success are revenue growth, higher average selling prices, lower direct material costs, positive new order flow and reduced cash usage.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P9_S0	To support our opportunities to grow in our targeted markets, we continue to enhance the reliability and performance of our products by regularly developing new processes and enhancing training to assist those who apply, install and use our products.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P10_S0	An overview of our direction, targets and key initiatives follows:
1009759_15_ITEM7_P11_S0	1) Focus on Vertical Markets Within the distributed generation markets that we serve, we focus on vertical markets that we identify as having the greatest near-term potential.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P11_S1	In our primary products and applications (energy efficiency, renewable energy, natural resources, critical power supply, marine and transportation products), we identify specific targeted vertical market segments.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P11_S2	Within each of these segments, we identify what we believe to be the critical factors to success and base our plans on those factors.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P12_S0	During Fiscal 2015, we booked orders for 86.0 megawatts and shipped 91.4 megawatts of products, which combined with our backlog at March 31, 2014, resulted in 182.8 megawatts in backlog at the end of the fiscal year.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P12_S1	Our product shipments in Fiscal 2015 were: 49% for use in natural resources applications, 44% for use in energy efficiency applications and 7% for use in renewable energy applications.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P13_S0	Energy efficiency maximizes the use of energy produced by the microturbines, reduces emissions compared with traditional power generation and enhances the economic advantage to customers.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P13_S1	Energy efficiency applications use both the heat and electric energy produced in the power generation process.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P13_S2	Using the heat and electricity created from a single combustion process increases the efficiency of the system from approximately 30% to 75% or more.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P13_S3	The increased operating efficiency reduces overall greenhouse gas emissions compared with traditional independent sources such as power generation and local thermal generation and, through displacement of other separate systems, can reduce variable production costs.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P14_S0	Our microturbines can use renewable methane gases from landfills, wastewater treatment facilities and biogas from sources such as food processing, agricultural waste and cow, pig and chicken manure.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P14_S1	Capstone's microturbines can burn these renewable waste gases with minimal emissions, thereby, in some cases, avoiding the imposition of penalties incurred for pollution while simultaneously producing electricity from this "free" renewable fuel for use at the site or in the surrounding area.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P14_S2	Capstone's microturbines have demonstrated effectiveness in these applications and outperform conventional combustion engines in a number of situations, including when the gas contains a high amount of sulfur.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P15_S0	On a worldwide basis, there are thousands of locations where the drilling, production, compression and transportation of natural resources and other extraction and production processes create fuel byproducts, which traditionally have been released or burned into the atmosphere.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P16_S0	and gas exploration, production, compression and transmission sites both onshore and offshore as a highly reliable critical source of power generation.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P16_S1	In addition, our microturbines can use flare gas as a fuel to provide prime power.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P16_S2	Typically these oil and gas or mining operations have no access to an electric utility grid and rely solely on Capstone's microturbines for a reliable low emission power supply.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P17_S0	Because of the potentially catastrophic consequences of even momentary system failure, certain power users, such as high technology and information systems companies, require particularly high levels of reliability in their power service.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P17_S1	Management believes that Capstone's critical power supply offerings are the world's only microturbine powered Uninterruptible Power Source solutions that can offer clean, IT-grade power produced from microturbines, the utility or a combination of both.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P18_S0	Our technology is also used in hybrid electric vehicle ("HEV") applications.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P18_S1	Our customers have applied our products in hybrid electric mobile applications, including transit buses and trucks.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P18_S2	In these applications the microturbine acts as an onboard battery charger to recharge the battery system as needed.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P18_S3	The benefits of microturbine hybrids include extended range, fuel economy gains, quieter operation, reduced emissions and higher reliability compared with traditional internal combustion engines.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P19_S0	Our technology is also used in marine applications.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P19_S1	Our customers have applied our products in the commercial vessel and luxury yacht markets.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P20_S0	The most immediate market for our marine products is for use as ship auxiliaries.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P20_S1	In this application, the microturbines provide power to the vessel's electrical loads and, in some cases, the vessel is able to utilize the exhaust energy to increase the overall efficiency of the application, reducing overall fuel consumption and emissions.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P20_S2	The other application is similar to our HEV application where the vessel is driven by an electric propulsion system and the microturbine serves as an on board range extender.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P21_S0	2) Sales and Distribution Channels We seek out distributors that have business experience and capabilities to support our growth plans in our targeted markets.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P21_S1	A significant portion of our revenue is derived from sales to distributors who resell our products to end users.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P21_S2	We have a total of 97 distributors and Original Equipment Manufacturers ("OEMs").
1009759_15_ITEM7_P21_S3	In North America, we currently have 31 distributors and OEMs.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P21_S4	Outside of North America, we currently have 66 distributors and OEMs.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P21_S5	We continue to refine the distribution channels to address our specific targeted markets.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P21_S6	3) Service We provide service primarily through our global distribution network.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P21_S7	Together with our global distribution network we offer new and remanufactured parts as well as a comprehensive Factory Protection Plan ("FPP").
1009759_15_ITEM7_P21_S8	Through our global distribution network, we offer a comprehensive FPP for a fixed annual fee to perform regularly scheduled and unscheduled maintenance as needed.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P21_S9	Capstone provides factory and onsite training to certify all personnel that are allowed to perform service on our microturbines.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P21_S10	FPPs are generally paid quarterly in advance.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P21_S11	Our FPP backlog at the end of Fiscal 2015 and Fiscal 2014 was $61.2 million and $47.2 million, respectively, which represents the value of the contractual agreement for FPP services that has not been earned and extends through Fiscal 2029.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P21_S12	Service revenue in Fiscal 2015 was approximately 9% of total revenue.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P22_S0	We continue to invest in enhancements that relate to high performance and high reliability.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P22_S1	An important element of our continued innovation and product strategy is to focus on the engineering of our product hardware and electronics to make them work together more effectively and deliver improved microturbine performance, reliability and low maintenance cost to our customers.

1009759_15_ITEM7_P22_S8	Capstone plans to continue development of the engine as well as power electronics and software controls required for successful commercialization.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P22_S9	The second phase of the program is expected to incorporate further engine efficiency improvements, resulting in a product with a projected electrical efficiency of 42% and targeted power output of 370 kW. The DOE awarded us a grant of $5.0 million in support of this development program of which $3.9 million has been used through March 31, 2015.

1009759_15_ITEM7_P27_S0	Our discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of operations is based upon our consolidated financial statements, which have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America ("GAAP").
1009759_15_ITEM7_P27_S1	The preparation of these consolidated financial statements requires us to make estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenue and expenses and related disclosures of contingent liabilities.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P28_S0	including finite-lived intangible assets and fixed assets, bad debts, inventories, warranty obligations, stock-based compensation, income taxes and contingencies.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P29_S0	We base our estimates on historical experience and on various other assumptions that we believe to be reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P29_S1	Actual results may differ from these estimates under different assumptions or conditions.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P30_S0	Management believes that the following critical accounting policies affect our more significant judgments and estimates used in the preparation of our consolidated financial statements.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P31_S0	We evaluate the carrying value of long-lived assets, including intangible assets with finite lives, for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value of such assets may not be recoverable.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P31_S1	Factors that are considered important that could trigger an impairment review include a current-period operating or cash flow loss combined with a history of operating or cash flow losses and a projection or forecast that demonstrates continuing losses or insufficient income associated with the use of a long-lived asset or asset group.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P31_S2	Other factors include a significant change in the manner of the use of the asset or a significant negative industry or economic trend.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P32_S0	This evaluation is performed based on undiscounted estimated future cash flows compared with the carrying value of the related assets.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P32_S1	If the undiscounted estimated future cash flows are less than the carrying value, an impairment loss is recognized and the loss is measured by the difference between the carrying value and the estimated fair value of the asset group.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P33_S0	The estimated fair value of the assets are determined using the best information available.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P34_S0	On a quarterly basis, we assess whether events or changes in circumstances have occurred that potentially indicate the carrying value of long-lived assets may not be recoverable.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P35_S0	Intangible assets include a manufacturing license, technology, backlog and customer relationships.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P35_S1	We reevaluate the useful life determinations for these intangible assets each reporting period to determine whether events and circumstances warrant a revision in their remaining useful lives.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P35_S2	The Company performed an analysis as of March 31, 2015 and determined that no impairment was necessary.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P36_S0	Our inventories are valued on a first in first out ("FIFO") basis and at the lower of cost or market.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P36_S1	We routinely evaluate the composition of our inventories and identify slow-moving, excess, obsolete or otherwise impaired inventories.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P36_S2	Inventories identified as impaired are evaluated to determine if write-downs are required.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P36_S3	Included in this assessment is a review for obsolescence as a result of engineering changes in our product.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P37_S0	Future product enhancement and development may render certain inventories obsolete, resulting in additional write-downs of inventories.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P37_S1	In addition, inventories are classified as current or long-term based on our sales forecast and also, in part, based on our projected usage for warranty claims and service.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P38_S0	A change in forecast could impact the classification of inventories.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P39_S0	We provide for the estimated cost of warranties at the time revenue from sales is recognized.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P39_S1	We also accrue the estimated costs to address reliability repairs on products no longer under warranty when, in our judgment, and in accordance with a specific plan developed by us, it is prudent to provide such repairs.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P39_S2	We estimate warranty expenses based upon historical and projected product failure rates, estimated costs of parts, labor and shipping to repair or replace a unit and the number of units covered under the warranty period.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P39_S3	While we engage in extensive quality programs and processes, our warranty obligation is affected by failure rates and service costs in correcting failures.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P39_S4	As we have more units commissioned and longer periods of actual performance, additional data becomes available to assess future warranty costs.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P39_S5	When we have sufficient evidence that product changes are altering the historical failure occurrence rates, the impact of such changes is then taken into account in estimating future warranty liabilities.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P40_S0	cost of repair and product enhancements, becomes available.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P40_S1	Should actual failure rates or service costs differ from our estimates, revisions to the warranty liability would be required and could be material to our financial condition, results of operations and cash flow.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P41_S0	Our revenue consists of sales of products, parts, accessories and service, which includes FPPs, net of discounts.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P41_S1	Our distributors purchase products, parts and FPPs for sale to end users and are also required to provide a variety of additional services, including application engineering, installation, commissioning and post-commissioning service.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P41_S2	Our standard terms of sales to distributors and direct end users include transfer of title, care, custody and control at the point of shipment, payment terms ranging from full payment in advance of shipment to payment in 90 days, no right of return or exchange, and no post-shipment performance obligations by us except for warranties provided on the products and parts sold.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P41_S3	We recognize revenue when all of the following criteria are met: persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, delivery has occurred or service has been rendered, selling price is fixed or determinable and collectability is reasonably assured.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P42_S0	Service revenue derived from time and materials contracts is recognized as the service is performed.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P43_S0	FPP contracts are agreements to perform certain agreed-upon service to maintain a product for a specified period of time.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P43_S1	Service revenue derived from FPP contracts is recognized on a straight-line basis over the contract period.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P43_S2	We occasionally enter into agreements that contain multiple elements, such as equipment, installation, engineering and/or service.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P43_S3	Trade accounts receivable are recorded at the invoiced amount and typically non-interest bearing.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P44_S0	We maintain allowances for estimated losses resulting from the inability of our customers to make required payments and other accounts receivable allowances.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P44_S1	We evaluate all accounts aged over 60 days past payment terms.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P44_S2	If the financial condition of our customers deteriorates or if other conditions arise that result in an impairment of their ability or intention to make payments, additional allowances may be required.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P45_S0	We have a history of unprofitable operations.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P45_S1	These losses generated significant federal and state net operating loss ("NOL") carryforwards.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P45_S2	We record a valuation allowance against the net deferred income tax assets associated with these NOLs if it is "more likely than not" that we will not be able to utilize them to offset future income taxes.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P45_S3	Because of the uncertainty surrounding the timing of realizing the benefits of our favorable tax attributes in future income tax returns, a valuation allowance has been provided against all of our net deferred income tax assets.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P46_S0	We currently provide for income taxes only to the extent that we expect to pay cash taxes, primarily foreign and state taxes.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P46_S1	It is possible, however, that we could be profitable in the future at levels which could cause management to determine that it is more likely than not that we will realize all or a portion of the NOL carryforwards.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P46_S2	Upon reaching such a conclusion, we would record the amount of net deferred tax assets that are expected to be realized.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P46_S3	Such adjustment would increase income in the period that the determination was made.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P47_S0	We recognize stock-based compensation expense associated with stock options in the statement of operations.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P47_S1	Determining the amount of stock-based compensation to be recorded requires us to develop estimates to be used in calculating the grant-date fair value of stock options.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P47_S2	We calculate the grant-date fair values using the Black-Scholes valuation model.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P48_S0	The use of Black-Scholes model requires us to make estimates of the following assumptions:
1009759_15_ITEM7_P49_S0	Expected volatility The estimated stock price volatility was derived based upon the Company's actual historic stock prices over the expected option life, which represents the Company's best estimate of expected volatility.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P50_S0	Expected option life The expected life, or term, of options granted was derived from historical exercise behavior and represents the period of time that stock option awards are expected to be outstanding.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P50_S1	Risk-free interest rate We used the yield on zero-coupon U.S. Treasury securities for a period that is commensurate with the expected life assumption as the risk-free interest rate.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P51_S0	The amount of stock-based compensation recognized during a period is based on the value of the portion of the awards that are ultimately expected to vest.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P51_S1	We estimate forfeitures at the time of grant and revise, if necessary, in subsequent periods if actual forfeitures differ from those estimates.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P52_S0	The term "forfeitures" is distinct from "cancellations" or "expirations" and represents only the unvested portion of the surrendered option.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P52_S1	We review historical forfeiture data and determine the appropriate forfeiture rate based on that data.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P52_S2	We re-evaluate this analysis periodically and adjust the forfeiture rate as necessary.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P52_S3	Ultimately, we recognize the actual expense over the vesting period only for the shares that vest.

1009759_15_ITEM7_P53_S3	The revenue decline during Fiscal 2015 in the North American market was primarily the result of a drop in the oil and gas market which has affected the timing of customer demand for our products compared to the same period last year.
