1009759_15_ITEM7_P108_S0	The Agreements include affirmative covenants as well as negative covenants that prohibit a variety of actions without Wells Fargo's consent, including covenants that limit our ability to (a) incur or guarantee debt, (b) create liens, (c) enter into any merger, recapitalization or similar transaction or purchase all or substantially all of the assets or stock of another entity, (d) pay dividends on, or purchase, acquire, redeem or retire shares of, our capital stock, (e) sell, assign, transfer or otherwise dispose of all or substantially all of our assets, (f) change our accounting method or (g) enter into a different line of business.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P108_S1	Furthermore, the Agreements contain financial covenants, including (i) a requirement not to exceed specified levels of losses, (ii) a requirement to maintain a substantial minimum monthly cash balance to outstanding line of credit advances based upon the Company's financial performance, and (iii) limitations on our annual capital expenditures.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P109_S0	Several times since entering into the Agreements we were not in compliance with certain covenants under the Credit Facility.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P109_S1	In connection with each event of noncompliance, Wells Fargo waived the event of default and, on several occasions, the Company amended the Agreements in response to the default and waiver.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P109_S2	The following summarizes the recent events, amendments and waivers:
1009759_15_ITEM7_P110_S0	On September 16, 2014, the Company entered into a letter agreement (the "Letter Agreement") with Wells Fargo.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P110_S1	The Letter Agreement extended the maturity date under the Company's Credit and Security Agreement (Ex-Im Subfacility) from September 30, 2014 to September 1, 2017.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P110_S2	The Letter Agreement also, among other things, changed the annual facility fee due to Wells Fargo under the Credit and Security Agreement (Ex-Im Subfacility) and revised the calculation of Capstone's borrowing base under the portion of the Credit Facility established by the Credit and Security Agreement (Ex-Im Subfacility) to increase the borrowing limit related to inventory.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P110_S3	As of September 30, 2014, the Company determined that it was not in compliance with the financial covenant contained in the amended Agreements regarding the Company's annual net income for Fiscal 2015.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P110_S4	On November 3, 2014, the Company received from Wells Fargo a waiver of such noncompliance and entered into an amendment to amend the financial covenants regarding net income for Fiscal 2015.

1009759_15_ITEM7_P111_S1	On June 10, 2015, the Company received from Wells Fargo a waiver of such noncompliance, and the Company and Wells Fargo entered into an amendment to the Agreements which set the financial covenants for Fiscal 2016.

1009759_15_ITEM7_P112_S0	If we had not obtained the waivers and amended the Agreements as described above, we would not be able to draw additional funds under the Credit Facility.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P112_S1	In addition, the Company has pledged its accounts receivables, inventories, equipment, patents and other assets as collateral for its Agreements, which would be subject to seizure by Wells Fargo if the Company were in default under the Agreements and unable to repay the indebtedness.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P112_S2	Wells Fargo also has the option to terminate the Agreements or accelerate the indebtedness during a period of noncompliance.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P112_S3	Based on our current forecasts, management believes we will maintain compliance with the covenants contained in the amended Agreements for at least the next twelve months.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P112_S4	If a covenant violation were to occur, management would attempt to negotiate a waiver of compliance from Wells Fargo.

1009759_15_ITEM7_P126_S0	In April 2015, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (the "FASB") issued Accounting Standard Update ("ASU") 2015-03, Interest Imputation of Interest (Subtopic 835-30).
1009759_15_ITEM7_P126_S1	The ASU was issued as part of FASB's current plan to simplify overly complex standards.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P127_S0	This ASU requires that debt issuance costs related to a recognized debt liability be presented in the balance sheet as a direct deduction from the carrying amount of that debt liability.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P127_S1	The recognition and measurement guidance for debt issuance costs are not affected by this ASU.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P127_S2	The update requires retrospective application to all prior period amounts presented.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P127_S3	This update is effective for annual and interim periods beginning on or after December 15, 2015, with early application permitted for financial statements that have not been issued.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P127_S4	We are currently evaluating the potential impacts the new standard will have on our reporting process.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P128_S0	In August 2014, the FASB issued ASU 2014-15, Disclosure of Uncertainties About an Entity's Ability to Continue as a Going Concern ("ASU 2014-15").
1009759_15_ITEM7_P128_S1	ASU 2014-15 requires management to perform interim and annual assessments of an entity's ability to continue as a going concern within one year of the date the financial statements are issued and provides guidance on determining when and how to disclose going concern uncertainties in the financial statements.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P128_S2	Certain disclosures will be required if conditions give rise to substantial doubt about an entity's ability to continue as a going concern.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P129_S0	ASU 2014-15 applies to all entities and is effective for annual and interim reporting periods ending after December 15, 2016, with early adoption permitted.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P129_S1	We are currently evaluating the potential impacts the new standard will have on our reporting process.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P130_S0	In June 2014, the FASB issued ASU 2014-12, Accounting for Share-Based Payments When the Terms of an Award Provide That a Performance Target Could Be Achieved after the Requisite Service Period ("ASU 2014-12").
1009759_15_ITEM7_P130_S1	ASU 2014-12 requires that a performance target that affects vesting and that could be achieved after the requisite service period be treated as a performance condition.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P130_S2	As such, the performance target should not be reflected in estimating the grant-date fair value of the award.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P131_S0	ASU 2014-12 is effective for annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2015, with early adoption permitted.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P131_S1	We are evaluating the potential impacts of the new standard on our existing stock-based compensation plans.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P132_S0	In May 2014, FASB issued ASU 2014-09, Revenue from Contracts with Customers ("ASU 2014-09").
1009759_15_ITEM7_P132_S1	ASU 2014-09 supersedes nearly all existing revenue recognition guidance under U.S. GAAP.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P133_S0	The standard's core principle is that a company will recognize revenue when it transfers promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the company expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P133_S1	We are evaluating our existing revenue recognition policies to determine whether any contracts in the scope of the guidance will be affected by the new requirements.
1009759_15_ITEM7_P134_S0	ASU 2014-09 is effective for annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2016, including interim periods therein.
1009759_15_ITEM7A_P0_S0	We currently develop products in the U.S. and market and sell our products predominantly in North America, Europe and Asia.
1009759_15_ITEM7A_P0_S1	As a result, factors such as changes in foreign currency exchange rates or weak economic conditions in foreign markets could affect our financial results.
1009759_15_ITEM7A_P0_S2	As all of our sales and purchases are currently made in U.S. dollars, we do not utilize foreign exchange contracts to reduce our exposure to foreign currency fluctuations.
1009759_15_ITEM7A_P0_S3	In the future, as our customers, employees and vendor bases expand, we may enter into transactions that are denominated in foreign currencies.
1009759_15_ITEM7A_P1_S0	Our exposure to changes in the interest rates results primarily from our Credit Facility borrowings.
1009759_15_ITEM7A_P1_S1	As of March 31, 2015 we had $13.0 million of outstanding indebtedness subject to interest rate fluctuations.
1009759_15_ITEM7A_P1_S2	Based on these borrowings as of March 31, 2015, a hypothetical 100 basis point increase in the then current LIBOR rate would increase our interest expense by $0.1 million on an annual basis.
1009759_15_ITEM7A_P1_S3	The level of outstanding indebtedness fluctuates from period to period and therefore could result in additional interest.

1009759_15_ITEM9A_P0_S0	We maintain disclosure controls and procedures that are designed to ensure that the information required to be disclosed in the Company's reports under the Exchange Act is recorded, processed, summarized, and reported within the time periods specified in the SEC's rules and forms, and that such information is accumulated and communicated to management, including our Chief Executive Officer ("CEO") and Chief Financial Officer ("CFO"), as appropriate, to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure.
1009759_15_ITEM9A_P0_S1	In designing and evaluating the disclosure controls and procedures, management recognized that any controls and procedures, no matter how well designed and operated, can provide only reasonable assurance of achieving the desired control objectives.
1009759_15_ITEM9A_P1_S0	In connection with the preparation of this Form 10-K for the year ended March 31, 2015, an evaluation was performed under the supervision and with the participation of our management, including the CEO and CFO, of the effectiveness of the design and operation of our disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Rule 13a-15(e) under the Exchange Act).
1009759_15_ITEM9A_P1_S1	Based on this evaluation, our CEO and CFO have concluded that our disclosure controls and procedures are effective as of March 31, 2015 to ensure that the information required to be disclosed by us in reports we submit under the Exchange Act is recorded, processed, summarized, and reported within the time periods specified in the rules and forms prescribed by the SEC.
1009759_15_ITEM9A_P1_S2	Additionally, such information is accumulated and communicated to management, including our CEO and CFO, as appropriate, to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure.
1009759_15_ITEM9A_P2_S0	Our management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting.
1009759_15_ITEM9A_P2_S1	Internal control over financial reporting is defined in Rule 13a-15(f) or 15d-15(f) under the Exchange Act as a process designed by, or under the supervision of, the company's CEO and CFO and effected by the company's board of directors, management and other personnel, to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with GAAP and includes those policies and procedures that:
1009759_15_ITEM9A_P3_S0	Pertain to the maintenance of records that in reasonable detail accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the company's assets; Provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with GAAP, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and Provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of the company's assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
1009759_15_ITEM9A_P4_S0	We conducted an evaluation of the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting based on the 1992 framework in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organization of the Treadway Commission.
1009759_15_ITEM9A_P4_S1	Based on our evaluation under the 1992 framework in Internal Control Integrated Framework, our management concluded that the Company maintained effective internal control over financial reporting as of March 31, 2015.
1009759_15_ITEM9A_P5_S0	KPMG LLP, the Company's independent registered public accounting firm, has issued a report on the Company's internal control over financial reporting.
1009759_15_ITEM9A_P5_S1	The report of KPMG LLP follows.
1009759_15_ITEM9A_P6_S0	Projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risks that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1009759_15_ITEM9A_P7_S0	There was no change in the Company's internal control over financial reporting (as defined in Rules 13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f) under the Exchange Act) during the Company's most recently completed fiscal quarter that has materially affected, or is reasonably likely to materially affect, the Company's internal control over financial reporting, except for the remediation steps to address the material weakness in internal control over financial reporting described below.
1009759_15_ITEM9A_P8_S0	As previously disclosed in our Annual Report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2014, although there were no material errors that resulted from control deficiencies, we identified a material weakness in our risk assessment process, specifically our internal controls related to the design of control activities involving FPP revenue, inventory and cost of goods sold as it relates to inventory.
1009759_15_ITEM9A_P8_S1	We have remediated all three of the measures related to the material weakness by enhancing the procedures related to (a) the design of control activities with respect to the completeness and accuracy of our FPP revenue calculation, (b) the adequacy of documentation with respect to certain judgmental determinations used in the inventory reserve analysis and (c) the investigation of inventory discrepancies through subcontractor year-end verification.
1009759_15_ITEM9A_P8_S2	Management is committed to improving the Company's internal control processes and believes the remediation measures have strengthened the design and operating effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting.
1009759_15_ITEM9A_P9_S0	We have audited Capstone Turbine Corporation's internal control over financial reporting as of March 31, 2015, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework (1992) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO).
1009759_15_ITEM9A_P9_S1	Capstone Turbine Corporation's management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting, included in the accompanying Management's Annual Report on Internal Control over Financial Reporting.
1009759_15_ITEM9A_P9_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Company's internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
1009759_15_ITEM9A_P10_S0	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1009759_15_ITEM9A_P10_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
1009759_15_ITEM9A_P10_S2	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, and testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk.
1009759_15_ITEM9A_P10_S3	Our audit also included performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
1009759_15_ITEM9A_P10_S4	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1009759_15_ITEM9A_P11_S0	A company's internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
1009759_15_ITEM9A_P11_S1	A company's internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company's assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
1009759_15_ITEM9A_P12_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
1009759_15_ITEM9A_P12_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1009759_15_ITEM9A_P13_S0	In our opinion, Capstone Turbine Corporation maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of March 31, 2015, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework (1992) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO).

1009759_15_ITEM15_P8_S2	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.

1009759_15_ITEM15_P15_S0	Capstone Turbine Corporation (the "Company") develops, manufactures, markets and services microturbine technology solutions for use in stationary distributed power generation applications, including cogeneration (combined heat and power ("CHP"), integrated combined heat and power ("ICHP"), and combined cooling, heat and power ("CCHP")), renewable energy, natural resources and critical power supply.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P15_S1	In addition, the Company's microturbines can be used as battery charging generators for hybrid electric vehicle applications.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P16_S0	The Company was organized in 1988 and has been commercially producing its microturbine generators since 1998.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P17_S0	The Company has incurred significant operating losses since its inception.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P17_S1	Management anticipates incurring additional losses until the Company can produce sufficient revenue to cover its operating costs.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P18_S0	To date, the Company has funded its activities primarily through private and public equity offerings.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P19_S0	This Annual Report on Form 10-K (this "Form 10-K") refers to the Company's fiscal years ending March 31 as its "Fiscal" years.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P20_S0	The consolidated financial statements have been prepared assuming the Company will continue as a going concern, which contemplates the realization of assets and satisfaction of liabilities in the normal course of business.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P21_S0	The Company's net loss from operations for the Fiscal years ended 2015, 2014 and 2013 was $30.9 million, $15.3 million and $22.0 million, respectively.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P21_S1	The lower than expected revenue during Fiscal 2015 and an increase in accounts receivable allowance provided for two customers was the primary cause of the increase in the net loss from operations.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P21_S2	The Company's cash and cash equivalents as of March 31, 2015 and 2014 were $32.2 million and $27.9 million, respectively.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P21_S3	The Company's working capital requirements during Fiscal 2015 were higher than planned primarily as a result of lower than anticipated inventory turns and reductions to accounts payable as a result of payments made by the Company.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P21_S4	Additionally, the Company did not fully achieve its planned number of product shipments primarily as a result of continuing geopolitical instability in Russia and Ukraine, the dramatic downturn of the oil and gas markets and a substantially stronger U.S. dollar making our products more expensive overseas.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P22_S0	Management has the ability to manage certain operating assets and liabilities, specifically the procurement of inventory and timing of payments of accounts payable, capital expenditures and certain operating expenses depending on the results of its operations to extend its cash and cash equivalents.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P22_S1	Management believes that existing cash and cash equivalents are sufficient to meet the Company's anticipated cash needs for at least the next twelve months.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P22_S2	In the event that our anticipated cash needs change, it is possible that the Company may need to raise additional capital in the future.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P22_S3	The Company may seek to raise funds by selling additional securities to the public or to selected investors or by obtaining additional debt financing.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P22_S4	There is no assurance that the Company will be able to obtain additional funds on commercially favorable terms, or at all.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P22_S5	If the Company raises additional funds by issuing additional equity or convertible debt securities, the fully diluted ownership percentages of existing stockholders will be reduced.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P22_S6	In addition, any equity or debt securities that the Company would issue may have rights, preferences or privileges senior to those of the holders of its common stock.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P23_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company, Capstone Turbine International, Inc., its wholly owned subsidiary that was formed in June 2004, and Capstone Turbine Singapore Pte., Ltd., its wholly owned subsidiary that was formed in February 2011, after elimination of inter-company transactions.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P24_S0	The Company considers only those investments that are highly liquid and readily convertible to cash with original maturities of three months or less at date of purchase as cash equivalents.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P25_S0	The carrying value of certain financial instruments, including cash equivalents, accounts receivable, accounts payable, revolving credit facility and notes payable approximate fair market value based on their short-term nature.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P25_S1	See Note 10 Fair Value Measurements, for disclosure regarding the fair value of other financial instruments.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P26_S0	Accounts Receivable Trade accounts receivable are recorded at the invoiced amount and are typically non-interest bearing.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P26_S1	The Company maintains allowances for estimated losses resulting from the inability of customers to make required payments and other accounts receivable allowances.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P27_S0	Inventories The Company values inventories at first in first out ("FIFO") basis and lower of cost or market.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P27_S1	The composition of inventory is routinely evaluated to identify slow-moving, excess, obsolete or otherwise impaired inventories.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P27_S2	Inventories identified as impaired are evaluated to determine if write-downs are required.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P27_S3	Included in the assessment is a review for obsolescence as a result of engineering changes in the Company's products.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P28_S0	All inventories expected to be used in more than one year are classified as long-term.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P28_S1	Inventory charges increased approximately $1.0 million during Fiscal 2015 compared to Fiscal 2014 primarily as a result of an allowance for slow-moving inventory related to the waste heat recovery generators.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P29_S0	Depreciation and Amortization Depreciation and amortization are provided for using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the related assets, ranging from two to ten years.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P29_S1	Leasehold improvements are amortized over the lease term or the estimated useful lives of the assets, whichever is shorter.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P29_S2	Intangible assets that have finite useful lives are amortized over their estimated useful lives using the straight-line method with the exception of the backlog of 100 kW microturbines ("TA100") acquired from Calnetix Power Solutions, Inc. ("CPS").
1009759_15_ITEM15_P29_S3	Purchased backlog is amortized based on unit sales and presented as a component of cost of goods sold.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P30_S0	Long-Lived Assets The Company reviews the recoverability of long-lived assets, including intangible assets with finite lives, whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value of such assets may not be recoverable.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P30_S1	If the expected future cash flows from the use of such assets (undiscounted and without interest charges) are less than the carrying value, the Company may be required to record a write-down, which is determined based on the difference between the carrying value of the assets and their estimated fair value.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P30_S2	The Company performed an analysis as of March 31, 2015 and determined that no impairment was necessary.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P31_S0	Intangible assets include a manufacturing license, trade name, technology, backlog and customer relationships.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P32_S0	Deferred Revenue Deferred revenue consists of deferred product and service revenue and customer deposits.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P32_S1	Deferred revenue will be recognized when earned in accordance with the Company's revenue recognition policy.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P33_S0	The Company has the right to retain all or part of customer deposits under certain conditions.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P34_S0	Revenue The Company's revenue consists of sales of products, parts, accessories and service, which includes a comprehensive Factory Protection Plan ("FPP"), net of discounts.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P35_S0	distributors purchase products, parts and FPPs for sale to end users and are also required to provide a variety of additional services, including application engineering, installation, commissioning and post-commissioning repair and maintenance service.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P35_S1	The Company's standard terms of sales to distributors and direct end-users include transfer of title, care, custody and control at the point of shipment, payment terms ranging from full payment in advance of shipment to payment in 90 days, no right of return or exchange, and no post-shipment performance obligations by Capstone except for warranties provided on the products and parts sold.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P36_S0	Revenue from the sale of products, parts and accessories is generally recognized and earned when all of the following criteria are satisfied: (a) persuasive evidence of a sales arrangement exists; (b) price is fixed or determinable; (c) collectability is reasonably assured; and (d) delivery has occurred.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P36_S1	Delivery generally occurs when the title and the risks and rewards of ownership have substantially transferred to the customer.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P36_S2	Assuming all other revenue recognition criteria have been met, if it is determined that collection is not reasonably assured, revenue will not be recognized until collectability is reasonably assured, which is generally upon receipt of payment.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P36_S3	Management's estimates regarding the collectability of a particular sale may impact the timing of actual revenue recognized each period.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P37_S0	Service performed by the Company has consisted primarily of time and materials based contracts.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P37_S1	The time and materials contracts are usually related to out-of-warranty units.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P38_S0	Service revenue derived from time and materials contracts is recognized as the service is performed.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P39_S0	The Company also provides maintenance service contracts to customers of its existing installed base.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P39_S1	The maintenance service contracts are agreements to perform certain services to maintain a product for a specified period of time.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P39_S2	Service revenue derived from maintenance service contracts is recognized on a straight-line basis over the contract period.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P40_S0	Warranty The Company provides for the estimated costs of warranties at the time revenue is recognized.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P40_S1	The specific terms and conditions of those warranties vary depending upon the product sold and geography of sale.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P40_S2	The Company's product warranties generally start from the delivery date and continue for up to eighteen months.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P40_S3	Factors that affect the Company's warranty obligation include product failure rates, anticipated hours of product operations and costs of repair or replacement in correcting product failures.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P40_S4	These factors are estimates that may change based on new information that becomes available each period.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P40_S5	Similarly, the Company also accrues the estimated costs to address reliability repairs on products no longer in warranty when, in the Company's judgment, and in accordance with a specific plan developed by the Company, it is prudent to provide such repairs.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P41_S0	The Company assesses the adequacy of recorded warranty liabilities quarterly and makes adjustments to the liability as necessary.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P41_S1	When the Company has sufficient evidence that product changes are altering the historical failure occurrence rates, the impact of such changes is then taken into account in estimating future warranty liabilities.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P42_S0	The Company accounts for grant distributions and development funding as offsets to R D expenses and both are recorded as the related costs are incurred.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P42_S1	Total offsets to R D expenses amounted to $0.5 million, $1.4 million and $1.7 million for the years ended March 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P43_S0	Income Taxes Deferred income tax assets and liabilities are computed for differences between the consolidated financial statement and income tax basis of assets and liabilities.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P44_S0	the differences are expected to reverse.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P45_S0	Valuation allowances are established, when necessary, to reduce deferred income tax assets to the amounts expected to be realized.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P46_S0	Contingencies The Company records an estimated loss from a loss contingency when information available prior to issuance of its financial statements indicates that it is probable that an asset has been impaired or a liability has been incurred at the date of the financial statements and the amount of the loss can be reasonably estimated.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P47_S0	Risk Concentrations Financial instruments that potentially subject the Company to concentrations of credit risk consist primarily of cash and cash equivalents and accounts receivable.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P48_S0	At March 31, 2015, the majority of our cash balances were held at financial institutions located in California.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P48_S1	The accounts at these institutions are insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation up to certain limits.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P48_S2	Balances that exceed the insurance coverage aggregate to approximately $32.0 million as of March 31, 2015.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P49_S0	The Company places its cash and cash equivalents with high credit quality institutions.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P49_S1	The Company performs ongoing credit evaluations of its customers and maintains an allowance for potential credit losses.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P50_S0	Sales to Horizon Power Systems ("Horizon"), one of the Company's domestic distributors, accounted for 17%, 12% and 27% of our revenue for the years ended March 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P50_S1	Sales to BPC Engineering ("BPC"), one of the Company's Russian distributors, accounted for 11%, 17% and 11% of our revenue for the years ended March 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P50_S2	Sales to E-Finity Distributed Generation, LLC ("E-Finity), one of the Company's domestic distributors, accounted for 19% of our revenue for the year ended March 31, 2014.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P50_S3	Additionally, Optimal Group Australia Pty Ltd, one of the Company's Australian distributors, accounted for 17% of net accounts receivable as of March 31, 2015.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P50_S4	BPC, Electro Mecanique Industries ("EMI"), one of the Company's distributors in the Middle East and Africa, and E-Finity accounted for 26%, 18% and 16%, respectively, of net accounts receivable as of March 31, 2014.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P51_S0	During the three months ended March 31, 2015, the Company recorded approximately $7.1 million with respect to the accounts receivable allowance from BPC.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P51_S1	The Company determined that the collectability of this accounts receivable balance was not reasonably assured based on BPC's payment history and because the impact of the recent steep decline of the Russian ruble could continue to negatively impact its ability to pay its outstanding accounts receivable balance.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P51_S2	During the three months ended September 30, 2014, the Company recorded approximately $2.6 million with respect to the accounts receivable balance from EMI.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P51_S3	The Company determined that the collectability of this accounts receivable balance was not reasonably assured based on EMI's payment history.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P51_S4	The Company recorded bad debt expense of approximately $10.1 million, $0.2 million and $0.3 million for the years ended March 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P52_S0	Certain components of the Company's products are available from a limited number of suppliers.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P52_S1	An interruption in supply could cause a delay in manufacturing, which would affect operating results adversely.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P53_S0	Estimates and Assumptions The preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America requires management to make certain estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in the financial statements and accompanying notes.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P54_S0	with finite lives, product warranties, income taxes and other contingencies.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P54_S1	Actual results could differ from those estimates.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P55_S0	Basic loss per common share is computed using the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P55_S1	Diluted loss per share is also computed without consideration to potentially dilutive instruments because the Company incurred losses which would make such instruments antidilutive.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P56_S0	Outstanding stock options at March 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013 were 13.2 million, 12.9 million and 11.8 million, respectively.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P56_S1	Outstanding restricted stock units at March 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013 were 1.9 million, 2.1 million and 1.5 million, respectively.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P56_S2	As of March 31, 2015 and 2014, the Company did not have any warrants outstanding.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P56_S3	As of March 31, 2013, the number of warrants excluded from diluted net loss per common share computations was approximately 26.5 million.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P57_S0	Stock-Based Compensation Options or stock awards are recorded at their estimated fair value at the measurement date.

1009759_15_ITEM15_P61_S0	In April 2015, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (the "FASB") issued Accounting Standard Update ("ASU") 2015-03, Interest Imputation of Interest (Subtopic 835-30).
1009759_15_ITEM15_P61_S1	The ASU was issued as part of FASB's current plan to simplify overly complex standards.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P62_S0	This ASU requires that debt issuance costs related to a recognized debt liability be presented in the balance sheet as a direct deduction from the carrying amount of that debt liability.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P62_S1	The recognition and measurement guidance for debt issuance costs are not affected by this ASU.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P62_S2	The update requires retrospective application to all prior period amounts presented.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P62_S3	This update is effective for annual and interim periods beginning on or after December 15, 2015, with early application permitted for financial statements that have not been issued.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P62_S4	We are currently evaluating the potential impacts the new standard will have on our reporting process.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P63_S0	In August 2014, the FASB issued ASU 2014-15, Disclosure of Uncertainties About an Entity's Ability to Continue as a Going Concern ("ASU 2014-15").
1009759_15_ITEM15_P63_S1	ASU 2014-15 requires management to perform interim and annual assessments of an entity's ability to continue as a going concern within one year of the date the financial statements are issued and provides guidance on determining when and how to disclose going concern uncertainties in the financial statements.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P63_S2	Certain disclosures will be required if conditions give rise to substantial doubt about an entity's ability to continue as a going concern.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P64_S0	ASU 2014-15 applies to all entities and is effective for annual and interim reporting periods ending after December 15, 2016, with early adoption permitted.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P64_S1	The Company is evaluating the potential impacts the new standard will have on its reporting process.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P65_S0	In June 2014, the FASB issued ASU 2014-12, Accounting for Share-Based Payments When the Terms of an Award Provide That a Performance Target Could Be Achieved after the Requisite Service Period ("ASU 2014-12").
1009759_15_ITEM15_P65_S1	ASU 2014-12 requires that a performance target that affects vesting and that could be achieved after the requisite service period be treated as a performance condition.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P65_S2	As such, the performance target should not be reflected in estimating the grant-date fair value of the award.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P66_S0	The Company is evaluating the potential impacts of the new standard on its existing stock-based compensation plans.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P67_S0	In May 2014, the FASB issued ASU 2014-09, Revenue from Contracts with Customers ("ASU 2014-09").
1009759_15_ITEM15_P67_S1	ASU 2014-09 supersedes nearly all existing revenue recognition guidance under U.S. GAAP.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P68_S0	The standard's core principle is that a company will recognize revenue when it transfers promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the company expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P68_S1	The Company is evaluating its existing revenue recognition policies to determine whether any contracts in the scope of the guidance will be affected by the new requirements.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P69_S0	ASU 2014-09 is effective for annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2016, including interim periods therein.

1009759_15_ITEM15_P129_S0	The FASB has established a framework for measuring fair value in generally accepted accounting principles.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P129_S1	That framework provides a fair value hierarchy that prioritizes the inputs to valuation techniques used to measure fair value.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P129_S2	The hierarchy gives the highest priority to unadjusted quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities (level 1 measurements) and the lowest priority to unobservable inputs (level 3 measurements).
1009759_15_ITEM15_P129_S3	The three levels of the fair value hierarchy are described as follows:
1009759_15_ITEM15_P130_S0	Inputs to the valuation methodology are unadjusted quoted prices for identical assets or liabilities in active markets.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P131_S0	Inputs to the valuation methodology include:
1009759_15_ITEM15_P132_S0	If the asset or liability has a specified (contractual) term, the level 2 input must be observable for substantially the full term of the asset or liability.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P133_S0	Inputs to the valuation methodology are unobservable and significant to the fair value measurement.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P134_S0	The asset or liability's fair value measurement level within the fair value hierarchy is based on the lowest level of any input that is significant to the fair value measurement.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P135_S0	Valuation techniques used need to maximize the use of observable inputs and minimize the use of unobservable inputs.

1009759_15_ITEM15_P143_S0	The Company maintains two Credit and Security Agreements, as amended (the "Agreements"), with Wells Fargo Bank, National Association ("Wells Fargo"), which provide the Company with a line of credit of up to $15.0 million in the aggregate.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P143_S1	The line of credit can be increased to an amount up to $20.0 million upon the request of the Company pursuant to the amendment described below (the "Credit Facility").
1009759_15_ITEM15_P143_S2	In addition, Wells Fargo has provided the Company with a non-revolving capital expenditure line of credit up to $0.5 million to acquire additional eligible equipment for use in the Company's business pursuant to the amendment described below.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P143_S3	As of March 31, 2015, the Company had not requested that the maximum line amount be increased to an aggregate of $20.0 million pursuant to the Agreements.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P143_S4	The amount actually available to the Company may be less and may vary from time to time depending on, among other factors, the amount of its eligible inventory and accounts receivable.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P144_S0	As security for the payment and performance of the Credit Facility, the Company granted a security interest in favor of Wells Fargo in substantially all of the assets of the Company.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P144_S1	One of the Agreements will terminate in accordance with its terms on September 1, 2017 and the other one will terminate on September 30, 2017.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P145_S0	The Agreements include affirmative covenants as well as negative covenants that prohibit a variety of actions without Wells Fargo's consent, including covenants that limit the Company's ability to (a) incur or guarantee debt, (b) create liens, (c) enter into any merger, recapitalization or similar transaction or purchase all or substantially all of the assets or stock of another entity, (d) pay dividends on, or purchase, acquire, redeem or retire shares of, the Company's capital stock, (e) sell, assign, transfer or otherwise dispose of all or substantially all of the Company's assets, (f) change the Company's accounting method or (g) enter into a different line of business.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P145_S1	Furthermore, the Agreements contain financial covenants, including (i) a requirement not to exceed specified levels of losses, (ii) a requirement to maintain a substantial minimum cash balance relative to the outstanding line of credit advances, which was $11.8 million as of March 31, 2015, and (iii) limitations on the Company's annual capital expenditures.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P145_S2	The Agreements also define an event of default to include a material adverse effect on the Company's business, as determined by Wells Fargo.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P145_S3	An event of default for this or any other reason, if not waived, would have a material adverse effect on the Company.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P146_S0	Several times since entering into the Agreements the Company was not in compliance with certain covenants under the Credit Facility.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P146_S1	In connection with each event of noncompliance, Wells Fargo waived the event of default and, on several occasions, the Company amended the Agreements in response to the default and waiver.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P146_S2	The following summarizes the recent events, amendments and waivers:

1009759_15_ITEM15_P149_S0	terminate the Agreements or accelerate the indebtedness during a period of noncompliance.

1009759_15_ITEM15_P151_S0	The floating rate for line of credit advances is the sum of daily three month London Inter Bank Offer Rate ("LIBOR"), which interest rate shall change whenever daily three month LIBOR changes, plus applicable margin.

1009759_15_ITEM15_P151_S2	The applicable margin varies based on net income and the minimum interest floor is set at $66,000 each calendar quarter.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P151_S3	The Company's borrowing rate was 4.0% at each of March 31, 2015 and March 31, 2014.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P152_S0	The Company is also required to pay an annual unused line fee of one-quarter of one percent of the daily average of the maximum line amount and 1.5% interest with respect to each letter of credit issued by Wells Fargo.

1009759_15_ITEM15_P257_S0	Capstone Turbine Corporation (the Company ) established, effective May 1, 2002, the Capstone Turbine Corporation Severance Pay Plan (the Plan ), to provide severance pay benefits for eligible employees whose employment is involuntarily terminated without cause, subject to the terms of the Plan.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P257_S1	The Plan was subsequently amended on February 4, 2003 and on October 9, 2003 and on January 1, 2009, and the Company desires to amend and restate the Plan, effective February 1, 2010.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P258_S0	This document serves as both the Plan document and the summary plan description of the Plan.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P258_S1	This restated Plan replaces and supercedes the Plan prior to the effective date of the restatement.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P258_S2	The purpose of this Plan is to assist employees in their transition to finding new employment.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P258_S3	Benefits paid to an employee hereunder are not earned or otherwise accrued by an employee.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P259_S0	Regular full-time employees of the Company or its subsidiaries whose employment is involuntarily terminated under conditions described in Article III ( Eligible Employees ) will be eligible for benefits upon satisfaction of the terms and conditions described in this Plan.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P259_S1	For purposes of eligibility, a regular full-time employee is an employee who is a resident of the United States and is regularly scheduled to work at least 30 hours per week.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P259_S2	It does not include (i) employees who are designated by the Company as temporary, seasonal or intern, or (ii) individuals who provide services under an employee lease agreement, leased employees (defined in section 414(n) of the Internal Revenue Code) or independent contractors.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P259_S3	Employees of the Company who are eligible for severance under another Company plan or employment agreement are not eligible to receive duplicate benefits under this Plan.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P260_S0	An Eligible Employee may receive benefits under this Plan only if the Company terminates his/her employment without Cause and the Eligible Employee satisfies all conditions and covenants provided in the Plan.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P260_S1	For purposes of this Plan, Cause shall mean violation of company policy, fraud, willful malfeasance (or similar wrongful acts) or continuing neglect of job duties following notice of such neglect.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P261_S0	Benefits are conditioned on a loss of employment with the Company and its successors.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P261_S1	An individual shall not be eligible for benefits if, following termination of employment that is in connection with a Change in Business, he/she becomes employed or is offered employment by a successor to the Company in a position that is substantially similar to the position he/she had with the Company at the time of termination of employment.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P262_S0	A Change in Business is the sale or transfer of all or a portion of the assets or stock or a merger of Capstone or related companies, or the Company s cessation of conducting certain business activities that are formally or informally transferred to another organization.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P263_S0	You will be notified if you are eligible for benefits due to a reduction in force or job elimination.
1009759_15_ITEM15_P263_S1	However, you will not be an Eligible Employee and not entitled to benefits under the Plan if you are offered and do not accept a reasonable reassignment to another position with the Company following such reduction or elimination.

1009759_15_ITEM15_P320_S0	In connection with the annual report of Capstone Turbine Corporation (the "Company") on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2015, as filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on the date hereof (the "Report"), Darren R. Jamison, as Chief Executive Officer of the Company, and Jayme L. Brooks, as Chief Financial Officer of the Company, each hereby certifies, pursuant to 18 U.S.C. Sec. 1350, as adopted pursuant to Section 906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, that:
1009759_15_ITEM15_P321_S0	The information contained in the Report fairly presents, in all material respects, the financial condition and results of operations of the Company.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P0_S0	Capstone Turbine Corporation ( Capstone or the Company ) develops, manufactures, markets and services microturbine technology solutions for use in stationary distributed power generation applications, including cogeneration (combined heat and power ( CHP ), integrated combined heat and power ( ICHP ), and combined cooling, heat and power ( CCHP )), renewable energy, natural resources and critical power supply.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P0_S1	In addition, our microturbines can be used as battery charging generators for hybrid electric vehicle applications.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P1_S0	Microturbines allow customers to produce power on site in parallel with the electric grid or stand-alone when no utility grid is available.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P2_S0	Several technologies are used to provide on site power generation (also called distributed generation ) such as reciprocating engines, solar power, wind powered systems and fuel cells.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P2_S1	For customers who do not have access to the electric utility grid, microturbines provide clean, on site power with fewer scheduled maintenance intervals and greater fuel flexibility than competing technologies.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P2_S2	For customers with access to the electric grid, microturbines provide an additional source of continuous duty power, thereby providing additional reliability and potential cost savings.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P2_S3	With our stand alone feature, customers can produce their own energy in the event of a power outage and can use microturbines as their primary source of power for extended periods.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P2_S4	Because our microturbines also produce clean, usable heat energy, they provide economic advantages to customers who can benefit from the use of hot water, chilled water, air conditioning and heating.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P2_S5	Our microturbines are sold, installed and serviced primarily through our global distribution network.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P2_S6	Together we offer new and remanufactured parts as well as a comprehensive Factory Protection Plan ( FPP ).
1009759_16_ITEM1_P3_S0	Successful implementation of microturbines relies on the quality of the microturbine, marketability for appropriate applications, and the quality of the installation and support.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P4_S0	We believe we were the first company to offer a commercially available power source using microturbine technology.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P4_S1	Capstone offers microturbines designed for commercial, industrial and utility users with product offerings ranging from 30 kilowatts ( kW ) to one megawatt in electric power output.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P4_S2	Our 30 kW ( C30 ) microturbine can produce enough electricity to power a small convenience store.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P4_S3	The 65 kW ( C65 ) microturbine can produce enough heat to provide hot water to a 100 room hotel while also providing about one third of its electrical requirements.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P4_S4	Our 200 kW ( C200 ) microturbine is well suited for larger hotels, office buildings and wastewater treatment plants, among others.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P4_S5	By packaging the C200 microturbine power modules into an International Organization for Standardization ( ISO ) sized container, Capstone has created a family of microturbine offerings from 600 kW up to one megawatt in a compact footprint.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P4_S6	Our 600kW, 800kW and 1000 kW ( C1000 Series ) microturbines are well suited for utility substations, larger commercial and industrial facilities and remote oil and gas applications.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P4_S7	Our microturbines combine patented air bearing technology, advanced combustion technology and sophisticated power electronics to form efficient and ultra low emission electricity and cooling and heat production systems.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P4_S8	Because of our air bearing technology, our microturbines do not require liquid lubricants.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P4_S9	This means they do not require routine maintenance to change and dispose of oil or other liquid lubricants, as do the most common competing products.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P5_S0	Capstone microturbines can be fueled by various sources, including natural gas, propane, sour gas, renewable fuels such as landfill or digester gas, kerosene, diesel and biodiesel.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P5_S1	The C65 and C200 microturbines are available with integrated heat exchangers, making them easy to engineer and install in applications where hot water is used.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P6_S0	Our products produce exceptionally clean power.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P6_S1	Our natural gas fueled C65 and C200 microturbines were certified by the California Air Resources Board ( CARB ) as meeting its stringent 2007 emissions requirements the same emissions standard used to certify fuel cells and the same emissions levels as a state of the art central power plant.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P6_S2	Our C65 and C200 Landfill and Digester Gas systems were certified by the CARB as meeting its 2008 waste gas emissions requirements for landfill and digester gas applications.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P7_S0	On February 1, 2010, we acquired the 100 kW ( TA100 ) microturbine product line from Calnetix Power Solutions, Inc. ( CPS ).
1009759_16_ITEM1_P7_S1	The TA100 microturbine is most similar to the Capstone product design compared to other microturbine products in the industry.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P8_S0	During the quarter ended March 31, 2016, we decided to limit the production of TA100 systems on a case-by-case basis for key customers.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P8_S1	We will continue to remanufacture engines and provide spare parts to our existing TA100 customers.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P9_S0	We sell complete microturbine units, subassemblies, components and various accessories.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P9_S1	We also remanufacture microturbine engines and provide after market parts and services.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P9_S2	Our microturbines are sold primarily through distributors and Original Equipment Manufacturers ( OEMs ).
1009759_16_ITEM1_P9_S3	Distributors purchase our products for sale to end users and also provide application engineering and installation support.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P9_S4	Distributors are also required to provide a variety of additional services, including engineering the applications in which the microturbines will be used, installation support of the products at the end users sites, commissioning the installed applications and providing post commissioning service, including a comprehensive FPP.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P9_S5	Our distributors perform as value added resellers.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P9_S6	OEMs integrate Capstone s products into their own product solutions.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P10_S0	To assure proper installation of Capstone microturbine systems, we have instituted a Factory Trained Installer ( FTI ) training and certification program.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P10_S1	Personnel from our distributors and OEMs, as well as design engineering firms, contractors and end users attend this FTI training.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P10_S2	We offer to assist all customers by reviewing their installation designs to confirm that the technical requirements for proper operation have been met, such as electrical interconnections, load requirements, fuel type and pressure, cooling air flow and turbine exhaust routing.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P10_S3	As part of the microturbine commissioning process, we also receive a checklist to confirm that the final installation adheres to Capstone technical requirements before we accept any warranty obligations.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P10_S4	This is aimed at providing the end user with a proper installation that will operate as expected for the life of the equipment.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P11_S0	Through our global distribution network, we offer a comprehensive FPP for a fixed annual fee to perform regularly scheduled and unscheduled maintenance as needed.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P11_S1	Capstone provides factory and on site training to certify all personnel that are allowed to perform service on our microturbines.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P11_S2	Individuals who are certified are called Authorized Service Providers ( ASPs ), and must be employed by a distributor in order to perform work pursuant to a Capstone FPP.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P11_S3	The majority of our distributors provide these services.

1009759_16_ITEM1_P19_S0	Capstone microturbines are compact, lightweight and environmentally friendly generators of electricity and heat compared to competing technologies.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P19_S1	They operate on the same principle as a jet engine with the added capability of using a variety of commercially available fuels.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P19_S2	For example, our microturbines can operate on low British Thermal Unit ( BTU ) gas, which is gas with lower energy content, and can also operate on gas with a high amount of sulfur, known in the industry as sour gas.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P19_S3	Examples of these fuel sources include methane from facilities such as wastewater treatment plants, landfills and anaerobic digesters.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P20_S0	Our microturbines incorporate four major design features: advanced combustion technology, patented air bearing technology, digital power electronics and remote monitoring capability.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P21_S0	Our advanced combustion technology allows Capstone microturbines to achieve low emissions with a design geared towards manufacturability.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P21_S1	These low emission levels not only provide an environmentally friendly product, but also eliminate permitting requirements in several municipalities for continuously operated onsite power generation.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P22_S0	The air bearing system allows the microturbine s single moving assembly to produce power without the need for typical petroleum based lubrication.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P22_S1	Air bearings use a high pressure field of air rather than petroleum lubricants.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P22_S2	This improves reliability and reduces maintenance such as oil changes.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P23_S0	The electronic controls manage critical functions and monitor operations of the microturbine, such as; our electronic controls manage the microturbine s speed, temperature and fuel flow and communication with external networks and building management systems.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P23_S1	The power electronics coordinate with the grid when the units are operated in a grid connect mode and with the onboard battery when equipped for stand alone mode.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P23_S2	All control functions are performed digitally.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P23_S3	Performance is optimized, resulting in lower emissions, higher reliability and high efficiency over a variable power range.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P24_S0	Our proprietary Capstone Remote Monitoring Software ( CRMS ) allows end users to operate and manage the microturbine remotely.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P24_S1	Unlike the technology of other power sources that require on site monitoring and maintenance, the CRMS allows end users to monitor their microturbine systems remotely and efficiently.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P24_S2	This remote capability can provide end users with power generation flexibility and cost savings.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P25_S0	The electrical output of our units can be paralleled in multiple unit configurations through our Advanced Power Server product and a digital communications cable to serve larger installations requiring electrical loads up to ten megawatts.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P26_S0	in dual mode, where the microturbine operates connected to the electric utility grid or operates independently.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P27_S0	We also offer C65, C200 and C1000 Series ICHP systems.
1009759_16_ITEM1_P27_S1	These systems combine the standard C65, C200 and C1000 microturbine unit with an integrated heat recovery module that provides electricity and heats water.

1009759_16_ITEM1_P29_S1	We also sell microturbine components and subassemblies.
